content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Don't Starve is an indie game about...not starving. Or getting killed by spiders. Or werepigs. Or stupid, randomly spawning dogs...or, well, there's a lot of ways to die in this game besides just starving, and I'll leave it at that. Overall, it's a rewarding, if not incredibly challenging, experience.Usually, indie games are highlighted by either their story, design or gameplay, which may prove significantly more innovative or intriguing than your average AAA game. That's why we buy them. Don't Starve is...a little bit different, to say the least, in that it's not all that inspiring in terms of story or gameplay. Here's the story: you don't want to starve, and also there's this dapper looking gentleman who appears to be channeling the ghost of a douchy harmonium. In terms of gameplay, point-and-click or use WASD to move around and interact with your environment, etc, etc. It's nothing that special.BUT! The design and presentation of the game make up for this apparent lack and reveal that the game itself is not nearly as lacking as it may seem to the wandering eyes of you potential buyers. In terms of design, its quirky, dark, funny and heavily Tim Burton-ized. The art style is simple enough that it doesn't overstep the abilities of its indie designers but still appears fresh, pretty and new, and each character you unlock through surviving longer and longer is unique, with his or her own set of perks and weaknesses that can be amusing, annoying or just plain scary. There's a girl who's dead twin literally follows her around, or a lumberjack with a possessed axe and a dark, beaver-based secret. Personally, I hope for more characters to be added to the vanilla game or perhaps as DLC because the current roster gets unlocked pretty quickly on an good three or four runs through the game. Still, these characters are more interesting than what you'll pick up from most games at this price.And when you do delve deep into this game after many, many, many trial runs, you'll discover that there's actually a lot of lore and story to this world. This mostly begins after entering Adventure Mode (and if you die in this mode, it doesn't affect your progress in the sandbox world), which can be done by opening a door randomly generated in any of your played worlds. You progress through five unique and challenging worlds, and along the way, you get a chance to see some of this lore and will probably hunger for more. Don't Starve leaves a lot more questions unanswered than I would like, but it's all to the cruelly addicting benefit of the game itself.Finally, I should address the difficulty of this game. You probably won't make it past the first five or so days on your first try without customizing the world. It's not an easy game, lacks any form of tutorial at all and all enemies, from bosses to weak spiders, can be found in the overworld on Day 1. Yes, there are one-time respawn points if you find them, but if you die, then it's over. Sometimes those respawn points don't even spawn. Your forty days of surviving through the turmoil of winter? Screw it! Never happened! And that does kind of suck, but it all adds to the tension and atmosphere of the game itself. You don't get a tutorial in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ woods! No one saves you when you decide to attack a herd of water buffalo with a stick of meat! And that mushroom over there? What does it do? Oh wait, it drains all of your sanity and makes shadow creatures in your head eat off your face. That'll learn ya.So yes, Don't Starve is difficult, especially during the winter months. But this is a survival game about surviving in a magical survival forest full of pop culture references and musical instruments. It's not supposed to be easy. And I'll tell you, there's nothing more rewarding than making it past your longest survival time. And if it's too hard, then you can tweak the spawning in a customized world so that only friendly bunnies and happy flowers populate your world. And occasionally, Satanic trees possessed with the vengeance of a thousand sundered splinters will pop up and absolutely wreck everything you hold dear and precious, as was intended by the Founding Fathers.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2013
												  Terraria gameplay meets The Binding of Isaac creepy style.   Don't Starve is an odd game. It has no story, no instructions, doesn't offer much help. This is rarely a good thing. In this case it really really is. You get tossed in a strange, not to mention very dangerous, place with nothing but the clothes on your back.   First thing's first. The title. Don't Die wouldn't have had the same impact that Don't Starve has. Being honest, not starving, even though being tweaked countless times during beta, is a lot easier than not dying. The dangers are countless and unforgiving.   When it comes to graphics, the style is something to appreciate. Everything seems to have been drawn by a kid with too much imagination and that is actually remarkable.   When we look at games we look at certain things like story, graphics, gameplay, mechanics and so on. This being a personal opinion, I mostly look at gameplay and how good and fun it feels. Don't starve does that in style. From collecting twigs and grass you get to weild things from blow darts to magic wands, to wear from Log Suits to Miner hats and Football helmets, from gathering carrots and berries to creating a farm with plots to grow vegetables from quite an interesting variety. .   The best part about gathering food? You get to cook it. Cooking can be done at a simple fire that you build to survive the night or at a more complex Cooking Pot which allows you to combine to up to 4 items to create specific dishes from a nice variety of recipes.   As I mentioned above, you get to craft the tools and items you need to survive. The crafting system is interesting and it works great. You require certain items to do so.  Actually gathering the ingredients can be quite demanding and more often than not requires you to hunt some of the most dangerous creatures, a lot of the times costing you time and health that could cripple your survival or even end it.   The world itself is as it was in Terraria or Minecraft if you will. You encoutner different biomes each with its own rewards and dangers, from grass fields to rocky terrain, marshes and so on.   The goal of the game? There is none. You do everything you can to survive for as long as you can. The days survived counter is a testament of that. The in-game time is calculated in days in increments of 3: daytime, evening, night. The night time is the most dangerous time of the day as your field of view is limited, monsters roam around the world and your sanity gets drained a lot faster.   Your adventure time is also split into season. Winter is of course the most perilous season, requiring you to wear warm clothes or being near a big enough fire for fear of freezing to death.   On the topic of sanity. Sanity is an interesting mechanic. The more time you spend in the dark or fighting, for instance, your sanity gets drained. The more sanity you lose the more paranoid you become and shadow monsters, for a lack of a better description, start seeping into reality, from them creeping at the edge of your field of view to actually being able to attack you and you attack them.   The so called monsters, or should I call it prey, offer quite the challenge. From Beefalos to Tallbirds, Hounds and Tentacles that come out from the marsh, to Treeguards that intend to revenge their fallen brethren.   In the case of characters, WIlson comes out as the main protagonist but he is certainly not alone. The assortment of playable characters allows for different strategies. The other playable can be unlocked in an interesting fashion. You have to die to get experience and you get experience based on the number of days you survived.   The main conclusions are that even though permadeath causes you to obviously start from the beginning again and can prove tedious at times, the urge to see how long you survive and adapting your strategies as such provides quite the reward when you see the days survived counter go beyond your last try.   The other main conclusion would be that for the current price, the value is undeniable.9/10

Posted: July 12, 2014
												A great survival game with many hours sunk into it.  I'm not too fond of the giants DLC however -- while it adds many nice new features, I find it makes the game much too heavy on it's 'perma death' genre.  Chances are, you will lose your sanity and die before you're able to explore many parts of the game.I recommend starting by customizing your map settings...disabling the giants and perhaps even lowering the rate at which your sanity lowers.  Unless ofcourse, you're the gamer who enjoys dying over and over again...then the default settings should be ideal for you.I still enjoy this game and find myself comming back...there's also a decent mod community in steam's workshop.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												The title says it all. Don't Starve is one of those addictive survival games, delivering you with the idea that your character(s) lives are at stake. Alike many other survival games it aims to make the idea of food a priority, and the rest will seamlessly fall into place. However Don't Starve wouldn't be complete without its amazing mod support, in which you can build new stuctures or delve into new stories. The options are endless! Some of the mods can't support some of the options in the vanilla game, causes crashes and save wiping issues. Faced with alot of hideous monsters and natural dangers, Don't Starve is one of the best survival games on the market!Pros: Fun survival, great mod support.       Cons: Mods can cause crashes, would love to see it multiplayer~8.5/10~

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												If anything there is to say about Don't Starve is that it's probably the best survival game out there at this moment. Besides having a very interesting art style and a great sense of humor, there is a large amount of things to craft and the resource gathering sates the kleptomaniac in me. All those grass and twigs you spent the past 30 min picking up? Yea you're going to need them. Unlike games such as Fallout where you can kind of just pick up things you want and avoid small drops, you're going to want to get everything you can. Nothing you find in the game is worthless, every drop and resource has a purpose which is a nice touch. There is an extensive wiki on this game, so if you need to know the use of a certain item or a crock pot recipe it's all available to you. I have to say a few things. One is that if you're dumb like me and didn't know that charcoal is burnt wood, let that be an indication of how to get it (Crock Pot is one of the most important items to survive well past winter). Two is that you might want to get the mod that shows your status (in numerical value) and shows the value for food. It may make the game less frustrating while not taking away from it. Third is that this is a game with perma-death (although there are multiple ways to revive yourself) and dying is the only way to earn experience to unlock most of the characters. Either way as you can tell I've sunk a large chunk of my time into this game and I highly recommend it.

												If you are a fan of sims,like survival games,have a love for Tim Burton styled graphics,great humor, and detailed game play mechanics then look no further. This game has a lot going for it .Game comes with adventure mode and sandbox mode.In adventure mode you go from world to world surviving til you find all the pieces of a item that takes you to the next world.The game has a ending in adventure mode so its worth doing if you wish to see it.There are different characters in the game you can play as each with their own plays style.Some characters can only be unlocked in adventure mode but with the power of mods you can unlock all of those characters if you wish.Speaking of mods,the game is quite mod friendly and has many mods on the steam workshop for your pleasure.You need to know how to do slight lua scripting if you want to do some beefy mods,but tweaking value sets of items in the game is easy to learn.You hunt,set traps,gather resources(pick things,chop down trees,etc),grow crops,fight mobs,lead pigs,herd beefalo(a sort of bison),make camps,dry meats,fish,craft items,etc in the game.The game has 4 main status types you need to worry about; Hunger,Sanity,Freezing, and Soggy.To take care of hunger you eat.Sanity is a interesting status because when you start to go insane you being to face new challenges that can end up killing you.The world itself starts to look different and does more than just look different. There are various ways you can treat your sanity as there are ways that can make you go insance.Freezing, occurs but only during the fall - winter season and can kill you if you do not keep yourself warm.Soggy is a condition that affects food and fire, you do not want soggy food trust me..There is far more to this game than even I explained in this lengthy review.Still not convinced? Watch some lets plays on youtube or just have blind faith in my opinion :PP.S. Don't Starve together incorportes many of the vanilla content for co-op but incorporates things not found in the vanilla game and even its DLC expansion Reign of Giants.As of this review Don't Starve Together (a standalone co-op sandbox) is in beta status.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Frustrating, and yet a great game to play! You got 1 life, and thats it! Don't starve is a very fitting name for this game, hunger will be one of your greatest opponents, but sanity comes in great as a second! At night, when the creepy monsters come.. When you're nearly dying of hungry and slowly start to go insane. That is when things start to get creepy! Where did that music come from!? Stay off my campfire! Oh no, My torch just ran out.....The art is simple but appealing, reminds me of Tim Burton a bit. The characters speak an amusing jibberish, and all of them have great up- and downsides depending on your playstyle.This game may cause some rage-quits, but it is very rewarding to stay alive! .. My Rage quit: . After i set my own farm on fire by accident with a very nervous Willow (character, who loves fire a tad too much) my hp started to drop because i was starving without my crops. A few minutes later 3 hounds came and ate me. Damnit! Mother of all ragequits.. And yet i started to play again within a day. It's just so appealing. The Reign of Giants DLC is fun, but not my cup-o-tea. I prefer the normal version. But it is fun to mix and match up at times, i would still recommend atleast trying it.

Posted: February 27
												I never would've thought that my 6-yo daughter would become interested in videogames because of this game.  It's awesome! She sits and suggests all kinds of things that we should try to make with various objects found, she wants me to build a house and "GET BACK TO THE HOUSE!" When it gets dark...and then she wants to explore when it's light. This is a truely bonding experience and I've found it so very enjoyable.She asks about and references "Don't Starve" in day to day things and it is truely an amazing thing for us both. I collect Video Games from DOS-Atari-NES-SNES-and onward. Thank you for this game, it's really fun I've always enjoyed it but I am so glad that it gained her interest as well.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Pros:1. The artstyle is amazing.2. New features are added regularly.3. The game is relatively bug-free.4. Great season-cycles and day-night cycles.5. Clear end-game goals.Cons:1. I think there could be more craftable items.2. Extremely unforgiving. I think there should be some mechanism that allows you to get back to base from the resurrection stone otherwise it gets too hard if you die in winter.Overall, its an excellent game and I have made 4 of my other friends buy it as well. If you're an indie game lover and can't commit to long gaming sessions, then this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												The game is indeed a great survival adventure and I don't regret wanting it and then buying it at all, but I also can't deny that I'm pretty disappointed in developer's choice of not supporting "Steam achievements". I like tracking my progress and my dedication for a game through those achievements, and displaying those was often the only way of showing off. I don't mind the perma-death and the frustration that comes with it, it's a survival game after all. It reminds me quite a lot of those WC3 survival maps, which is a good thing cause those were really fun, but also of Faster Than Light because of the frustration and perma-death parts.Anyway, the game is awesome, artsy without getting fancy, complex without getting complicated, and incredibly addictive. I can hardly wait the arrival of the multiplayer mode too.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Spawned in a new world to try to unlock some of the characters to try them out.After seeing Maxwell nag me about finding food I go North in a leisurely fashion with a tired expression on my face.I find what  looks to be a neat wooden fortress with skeleton bones and a chest right at the entrance.I open the chest and there's a "Fire Staff" that I briefly see before I hear a burning sound.I catch on fire and run away as my protagonist says "Oops" as the once neat looking fortress is burning and I am left in awe at what just happened in the matter of my first minute of playing on this new world. I then died the next day to a Killer Bee.This game is genuine. 10/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Tim Burton meets Gathering / Crafting adventure game goodness.This game captures my imagination like very few others. What it lacks in immersion it makes up for in truckloads of creativity and art originality.Some of the mechanics feel a little "left by the wayside" such as combat, which to me has always seemed to work a little haphazzardly. But the exploration and curiosity factor are so over the top its very easy to forget such things might get in your way.The music and sound fit perfectly with the art style in a melancholy yet purposeful romp through a dark and twisted wonderland of putrid or warped settings.I've had a blast playing Don't Starve, on and off Steam. Don't let my Steam playtime fool you, I'm a long standing supporter of Don't Starve and highly recommend it to anyone with a penchant for slightly warped or morbid yet humorous adventures.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												8/10The game is ammazing and bloody addictive!!!The game is A lot of fun, You dont really get any instructions as to how to play the game. So a good way to figure it out is to use the WIKI here http://dont-starve-game.wikia.com/wiki/Don%27t_Starve_Wiki I've used this a number of time's to figure out things that are a bit confusing at the start.The Main goal of the game is to simply try to survive and "Dont starve" :D.....This game has kept be busy for ages, And I jenerally dont survive any longer than 14 days in the game.Another note worthy thing about the game, Is the Modding community. Lots of brilliant mods to make the game either harder or easyer. Really depends on how you like playing.The new DLC "Reign of Giants" Adds a lot to the game as well. Lots of new things to find, explore and figure out what they do. It's enough to confuse you again and make the game seem fairly fresh.As per normal with my higer rated games... DO YOUR SELF A FAVOUR AND GET IT. It's worth the price

content:
Posted: April 28, 2013
												This is a wilderness survival sandbox featuring lovecraftian horrors pig men jackalopes and other strange things. You start in a sandbox mode shanghied by the mysterious maxwell and can work through an adventure mode within the sandbox.You have 3 stat bars health hunger and sanity controling these stats is the key to surviving as long as possible. You build prototypes of new equipment and structures to advance in the game and increase your probability of long term survival. This is not another minecraft clone and is an awsome game despite lack of multiplayer. Hunting gathering trapping beekeeping crafting fishing herding, all possibilities in this immersive game. Overall definatley worth the price if you like sandbox games and survivalism in general intruiges you, give this game a try.

YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E31 Don't Starve and Don't Starve Together 

			Views: 179		

			Don’t Starve & Don’t Starve Together: Don’t Starve & its multiplayer component, Don’t Starve Together, is an indie sandbox survival game of the weird & mysterious variety.		

Don’t Starve & Don’t Starve Together: Don’t Starve & its multiplayer component, Don’t Starve Together, is an indie sandbox survival game of the weird & mysterious variety. Developed & published by Klei Entertainment. The gameplay is simple which is pretty common for Klei, the controls are nothing special which isn’t bad, the gameplay itself is mostly fun although I have some personal gripes with combat.But, first, let’s talk about the graphics, the game is an isometric 2.5D game, with this really intriguing dark pencil drawn art style, the fact that the world of Don’t Starve itself is this mysterious & weird world also lends itself to this type of art style. The music also reminds me of this sort of twisted carnival feel, with lots of weird strings & brass instruments used to set the tone, characters also speak with mashed up music tones from different instruments, sounding mostly unpleasant.So as it’s about survival, you’ll brave all the elements of the seasons, the ever present drain on your sanity & your belly grumbling. Don’t Starve also features plenty of dangerous creatures as well as some neutral ones ranging from the Pigmen to the aggressive fish like Merms & of course with the Reign of Giants DLC, Giant boss monsters like the Deerclops. It’s a pretty challenging game, don’t expect to survive very long with your first forays into Don’t Starve, you’ll die plenty of times but, never unfairly so, as you learn the game you will become a better survivor & the game rewards you for how long you survive by unlock more characters to play with a total of eleven to choose from all with their own strengths & weaknesses. The story of Don’t Starve is only accessible through the sandbox mode which you start in, if you wish to know how to get there, you’ll have to experiment to find out.My only real gripe is with the games ‘combat’, you interact with the world mainly with the mouse, you can hold the spacebar to pick up nearby objects which is really handy, you can use the mouse or keyboard to move around, but, when in combat, I only ever was able to use the mouse, this is a problem, since the world is flat it is very easy & common for things to get in the way. This is only exasperated when things are hectic, it’s very annoying when there is multiple enemies. There are several ways to avoid combat, but, when you must it’s a pain dealing with multiple enemies at once. Other than that gripe the game is just pure fun, the multiplayer part was so simple to setup I can’t find anything to complain about, it’s the whole single player game with friends up to six & it’s easy to use plus you get two copies for the one price so it’s pretty cheap. I personally love Don’t Starve, it was a bit to get into at first, mostly because I was failing a lot at the beginning, but, once I gave it a serious shot I began to get better & better & could survive a very long time before dying, if you like survival type games in general definitely check this out, if you don’t like a challenge, or don’t like indies (for some reason) or just don’t like things that aren’t 3D ultra-graphics & “realistic” then steer clear of the quirky world of Don’t Starve, for the rest, we’ll be trying to survive despite the odds. Its $14.99 USD which is a pretty good deal, I’d recommend getting the bundle with the Reign of Giants for $18.99 USD which will give you a ton of stuff, or get the bundle that comes with a copy of Don’t Starve Together which includes the Reign of Giants DLC & bring a friend along for the ride! Thank you Klei Entertainment for awesome deals on awesome games!TL/DR; Don’t Starve is a wonderful survival game that doesn’t take itself too seriously but does offer a serious challenge for new comers. It’s got a very unique art style. The game is simple to play & simple to run with the sandbox goal of ‘survive’, it holds no hands & still expects you to succeed, it’s a fun game, & its multiplayer component Don’t Starve Together makes the experience even better with the ability to bring friends along for the suffering. I highly recommend check out both titles, they offer good deals for the single & multiplayer experience, unless you can’t stand the look of the game, or need that “realistic” approach to survival then check out Don’t Starve & Don’t Starve Together! -Double Thumbs Up from Royial

Posted: December 21, 2014
												This is a great game, I've suggested it multiple times to anyone watching my twitch channel while playing it. It's got an amazing Tim Burton-eque art style with plenty of survival aspects. The world is randomly generated so you'll not get the same map multiple times unless you wish to (there's an option to retry if you die on current map).Many people ask, "How do you get further than 10 - 20 days"? Practice, play the game, it's a survival game. Explore, craft stuff and mainly look at your surroundings for what's most helpful (beefao).Overall I'd recommend this game to anyone who loves Survival games, give it a try and if you get stuck there's an always growing wiki page for the game. You're going to die, it's a feature.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Don't Starve is one of those games where the only word that justifies it's quality and content is "perfection". It is such a complete experience, it has everything you would want in a survival game, and the level of content is monumentous. The one thing that really makes this game a treasure is the simplicity. What? You might ask. I will try to explain:The UI/ menus are perfectly uncomplex. They are neat, responsive and incredibly easy to navigate as everything is very well organized.The inventory spaces are placed neatly at the bottom of the screen and are always available to you. you have the option of organizing your materials into a few groups with slight spaces between lots of inventory slots. The clicking + dragging mechanism makes this process so much easier. I often organize all my edibles into one group, main building materials into another and tools/ armours/ weapons into another. The crafting system is also very easy to grasp. You can click whatever it is you want to build in the menu to the left and see what kind of resources you need to craft that item, with pictures of the actual items which makes the whole identifying process a breeze. The map is excellent. You can see (as far as you have travelled) key locations such as berry bushes, forests, different biomes e.t.c... You can also see where you've built stuff, if you have. This is very important if you don't want to get lost!The actual physical game map that you travel on is amazing. Resources are easy to find, click and collect. Your main tools (hatchet, pick-axe and shovel) require the most basic resources so you will easily be able to replace them without much hassle. This is also probably the only game where people won't question your pathological excitement over poop.Trust me, you will have so much fun just collecting hordes of resources and then putting them to use and generally just trying to survive another day. The game does get difficult, especially if you have the expansion enabled, which offers a whole new and exciting experience, but even if you fail, you'll want to immediately start again and perhaps learn from your previous mistakes and do things differently. I simply cannot find one negative aspect in this game, it is, as I said before, perfection.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												One of the most difficult games I've ever played, yet I keep coming back for more. It'd be easy to stop playing out of frustration, the game doesn't teach you anything and you learn simply by doing. With every death means starting over from scratch, the permadeath is both punishing and extremely rewarding to see how far you will get and how you must adjust your strategy in order to survive. The odds are stacked against you, but it never feels unfair. There is always something you could have done better or a different route you could have taken that may have lead to you living longer. Believe it or not you can even beat this game, or so I've heard.Nothing is more satisfying than figuring out a new mechanic while you are playing simply from experimentation, this game is so finely tuned and balanced that it must've been a nightmare for the devs to make. The combat is excellent yet simple and easy to understand, it is really all you could ask for in a Survival Crafting type game. And to make things even better the Multiplayer version of the game is even more fun, although not yet as feature complete as the singleplayer variant.The graphics are simply beautiful and extremely charming, nothing is more adorable than a sleeping homeless spider or a recently shaved beefalo. Add in unlockable characters, an excellent and tweakable world gen, and a plethora of mods on steam and you have a game that is well worth replaying.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												"AH♥♥♥♥♥♥HOUNDS!" i yelled, running through the woods in my attempts to escape the beasts. nearly bled out from making mysterious 2 legged pig men angry. What did i do to deserve this harsh world? Everything is fubat. Tree monsters hide in the forrests, spiders all over the place, insanity growing, hunger rising. Now this. Will this finally be my un-doing? To loose all i have gained onlt to start a life anew in the constantly hostile world. Only comparable to that of a schtizophranic mind. Beasts roam wild and all is dangerous. So few are the safeties of the fire in winter, and so rare is the safety of defences at night. Scavenging was hard enough to survive for the first few weeks. Now im going to die bie these blood thristy hounds of hell, or wherever such beasts were created. WAIT! a hole in the ground! I must get to it in order to survive. I jump down, only into darkness. Insanity is building, i see things in this dark tunnel. What awaits on the otherside? When i awaken my eyes, i am in a land i have yet not seen. My pursuers may not have easily given up, so i must run. Run fast, run far; only that i could if my stomach wasnt so empty, aarg i must have something to eat. Thankfully theres some bushes, but is that....a spiders nest? with little strength left, and a spear in hand, I make the short path to the dangerous bushes. To so i dont allow my self...to dont starve.9/10 for immersion: Very dangerous gameplay, you must be quick to think, or die from the elements of this vast and wierd place. I must say even being experienced in survival games, the night times in here are terrifying and detrimental to your health if you are un prepared to venture fourth in such time.10/10 for creativity: Very different sense of survivalism, if you like turkeys to be hulking 2 legged beasts, and any sort of socialness to be between a living pot following you, and pigmen. This is definitely for you.8/10 mechanics: Simple to use, as simple as click to move, use, everything else you need to know. Though i had alot of problems with picking up items behind other items. Which quickly became a nuissance.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Don't Starve has a simple premise: Survive as long as possible. However, that's easier said than done, and this game has quite a bit of content to make it an enjoyable game with plenty of replay value. At the start of the game, you can choose from a group of characters to play as. You will start with only one option, but unlock more as you play through the game. Most are unlocked through experience points that are gained after dying, with a few hidden through various other methods.After choosing your character, you wake up in the wilderness, and are forced to find materials to help yourself survive. There are other living things in this game, ranging from ordinary animals to strange beasts such as pig-men or walking trees, and a lot will try to kill you. You will need to keep yourself from starving by making use of food found throughout the world, keep your sanity high so you don't begin to hallucinate, and keep close to light at night so the shadow beasts won't kill you.  Traversing the large area you play in is a lot of fun, and hunting for materials can feel very rewarding when you finally find that last gold nugget you needed for a science machine. You'll need to plan very carefully, as a mistake can lead to death. The game gets addicting very quickly, and each death will only build your knowledge of the world until you can finally get the lucky attempt where you survive past winter. The sense of progression is fantastic, as you can easily see how much your hard work has paid off. The game is in a very nice art style that suits it very well, and the sound effects really add to the atmosphere the game has.Pros:+Fun and pleasant visuals+Excellent use of sounds+Variety of different characters makes each game interesting+Wide cast of allies and enemies you will meet+Addicting gameplay that allows the player to learn as they play more+DLC that's really worth the price+Steam workshop mods really add to the overall experienceCons:-The game is very confusing at first, and doesn't really offer any sort of tutorial. This isn't too much of a problem, but can make the game really confusing for some playersIf I had to give the game a score, it would be a 9/10. The lack of direction at the very start is the only potential issue I can think of, and even that isn't much of a problem for most people, myself included. I highly recommend this game, especially now that Don't Starve Together is in beta!

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												This game for me was a huge surprise , first impressions was like Tim Burton made this game. The environment is so cartoonist and dark, very nice. Well like the game name says, 'Don't Starve', this is our main goal, survive, make our own corn field, survive the winter - Winter Is Coming - and fight against some animals. Days will pass on DS, and are only 3 things that can kill you, hungry monsters or if you get bored. And why i say this? Well, like in any survival game you need to survive, but you need to build things and some times take a long time, and you may have luck or not to find those material fast. After some in-game days, you can specialize your crafting in one way or another, but the first real-time hour will always be kind of similar. Which means it’s not fun any more after a point, and you’ll start to really dread the endgame, for the wrong reasons.Another inconvenient could be the world generation, you can get a nice world like a few meters away from you, you find a boomerang and some provisions or you have generated a bad world and you won't find anythng good.This game also lacks on some details like not having a mini map on Hud and others things, but don't worry to much because there are mods that you can add to the game to make it perfect. Now the biggest things the game should have, Multiplayer! This has been asked so many times and the answer is always no, but i kind understand it because is a survival, and you should survive alone. I'm pretty happy with this game and although i don't have many hours i expect to play more on future, also huge amen to Klei Entertainment for making such awesome game! ~ 8/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Don't Starve has a simple premise: Survive as long as possible. However, that's easier said than done, and this game has quite a bit of content to make it an enjoyable game with plenty of replay value. At the start of the game, you can choose from a group of characters to play as. You will start with only one option, but unlock more as you play through the game. Most are unlocked through experience points that are gained after dying, with a few hidden through various other methods.After choosing your character, you wake up in the wilderness, and are forced to find materials to help yourself survive. There are other living things in this game, ranging from ordinary animals to strange beasts such as pig-men or walking trees, and a lot will try to kill you. You will need to keep yourself from starving by making use of food found throughout the world, keep your sanity high so you don't begin to hallucinate, and keep close to light at night so the shadow beasts won't kill you.  Traversing the large area you play in is a lot of fun, and hunting for materials can feel very rewarding when you finally find that last gold nugget you needed for a science machine. You'll need to plan very carefully, as a mistake can lead to death. The game gets addicting very quickly, and each death will only build your knowledge of the world until you can finally get the lucky attempt where you survive past winter. The sense of progression is fantastic, as you can easily see how much your hard work has paid off. The game is in a very nice art style that suits it very well, and the sound effects really add to the atmosphere the game has.Pros:+Fun and pleasant visuals+Excellent use of sounds+Variety of different characters makes each game interesting+Wide cast of allies and enemies you will meet+Addicting gameplay that allows the player to learn as they play more+DLC that's really worth the price+Steam workshop mods really add to the overall experienceCons:-The game is very confusing at first, and doesn't really offer any sort of tutorial. This isn't too much of a problem, but can make the game really confusing for some playersIf I had to give the game a score, it would be a 9/10. The lack of direction at the very start is the only potential issue I can think of, and even that isn't much of a problem for most people, myself included. I highly recommend this game, especially now that Don't Starve Together is in beta!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												To all those who say there is no story, you obviously have not played enough. Inside the game there is an "adventure mode" which is basically story mode(and very challenging).Crafting is a primary part of the game. It starts very simply — you'll pick up items in the landscape to construct simple tools, necessary to break down more raw materials. The system expands all the way from grass and twigs up to scientific machinery, complex farms and magical devices. The tech tree has enormous depth and room for experimentation, all dependent on your priorities.I recommended this game to anyone who wants to have great time for a couple of hours.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												For such a simple objective--not starving (or dying by creature, cold, heat, darkness, or other means)--this game is extremely rich and complex.  It has two modes; a sandbox survival mode in which your goal is simply to explore and become self-sustaining, and an adventure mode in which your goal is to overcome harsh environments to complete a machine to move to the next world.  You can play either in the spirit of discovering how to construct, create, and build everything yourself or consult and external reference for help, but either way, you'll be presented with a challenge that will keep you occupied and wanting to go a little further for weeks.  I highly recommend it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												With a title like "Don't Starve", you'd think you'd only have to worry about finding food. And you would be sorely mistaken. The maps are randomly generated, so what was a problem for you last time you played might not be such an issue for you now. That said, the things that came easy last time may not be so simple this time. For example, I frequently found myself running out of food on my first few attempts, while things like developing new technology came easy. However later on food was a bit easier to find, but I had trouble finding the stone and gold needed to unlock new recipes. THEN once I'd finally found a balance, I made the foolhearty mistake of taking too long to light another torch at night. This game is extremely difficult and while normally a frustrating mechanic such as having to start over everytime you die would put me off, I found myself going, "Well, that sucked. But I wonder what's in store for me next time?" If you're like me and love a good adventure, even if it tests your patience a bit, check this title out. You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Don't Starve and Dwarf Fortress share one thing in common; losing is fun!The game itself is a huge learning experience, and you'll always get further (usually) the last time than you did the first time.  Even if you manage to make a self-sustaining base that was indeed somewhat indestructable, the game would lose a lot of what made it fun to begin with.  Of course, getting to said point requires said experience; which depending on the person may or may not actually come.It's brutal at first glance, but even after you get better; the game doesn't stop getting harder.  If anything, the longer you live, the more merciless nature itself gets.  If you're not prepared, then prepare to die!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2013
												Don't Starve is easily one of the best indie games available on Steam.In a nutshell, Don't Starve is a rogue-like survival game aimed specifically to punch you in your nuts so it can give you a taste of permadeath. It's main pros are:- A library of characters to choose, from Wilson, a intrepid scientist who can grow a beard, to Woodie, a Canadian lumberjack who has a terrible curse. - A immersive world full of things ready to be discovered, and possibly ready to wreck you up while it's at it.- A vast army of creatures that can possibly either help you or hinder your chances of survival.- Unforgiving deaths. You ♥♥♥♥ up, you die and restart. All of these combined make for a great game and it's easily reccomendable. Not to mention that Klei Entertainment, the company behind it all is fair and produces high quality products and they're trustable as a team.Oh yeah, I almost forgot. Hounds are little annoying♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that will be happy to ruin your day.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												This game for me was a huge surprise , first impressions was like Tim Burton made this game. The environment is so cartoonist and dark, very nice. Well like the game name says, 'Don't Starve', this is our main goal, survive, make our own corn field, survive the winter - Winter Is Coming - and fight against some animals. Days will pass on DS, and are only 3 things that can kill you, hungry monsters or if you get bored. And why i say this? Well, like in any survival game you need to survive, but you need to build things and some times take a long time, and you may have luck or not to find those material fast. After some in-game days, you can specialize your crafting in one way or another, but the first real-time hour will always be kind of similar. Which means it’s not fun any more after a point, and you’ll start to really dread the endgame, for the wrong reasons.Another inconvenient could be the world generation, you can get a nice world like a few meters away from you, you find a boomerang and some provisions or you have generated a bad world and you won't find anythng good.This game also lacks on some details like not having a mini map on Hud and others things, but don't worry to much because there are mods that you can add to the game to make it perfect. Now the biggest things the game should have, Multiplayer! This has been asked so many times and the answer is always no, but i kind understand it because is a survival, and you should survive alone. I'm pretty happy with this game and although i don't have many hours i expect to play more on future, also huge amen to Klei Entertainment for making such awesome game! ~ 8/10

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Is this game worth £11 you may ask? Silly question, of course! Inclusing the DLC too, this game is a bundle of amazingness. Don't starve is , if not, on it's way to becoming the best gaming experience around. The fact you get dropped into a completely random world full of so many things that can kill you is so much fun. Of course the main objective is to not starve, but there are so many other obstacles to overcome, and so many ways to do just that. Don't starve is an amazing game that has taken up around 100 hours of my time, and soon to be much, much more. It will soon be multiplayer, so being able to experience all the dangers, problems and sucesses but with some company is something to look forward to.If you do not have patience, then this game probably isn't the best idea. You start off with mainly grass and wood, but as the game flows on, you can be speeding around with a cane, a top hat and some turkey dinner! What could be better? This game just offers such a thrill. The fact it also has great replayability, with other characters and that you can edit your worlds however you like, making it more difficult or easy, or even install some mods made by the fabulous people in the Steam Don't Starve workshop!Overall, if you have some spare time, a bit of money and are looking for a good, fun game, then I definately recommend this one.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This game is plenty of fun delivered in a highly stylised fashion. There's more depth than you first expect; the game can be somewhat difficult and unforgiving at times, but it's always enjoyable.The only thing I'd recommend is to take it slow; don't rush in expecting to kill everything in sight and survive simply by stabbing and punching stuff. You need to build yourself up first before you can take on the big game.On top of that, the game has a good modding community; everything from new items, to tweaks to game mechanics to make things far easier or much harder, new fan-made characters and even total conversions (the base game comes with an official surivival horror themed TC).Overall, Don't Starve is well worth the money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												My review is based on all expansions, not really vanilla. I was attracted to this game due to its art style and cute little Chester. Little did I know this artsy survival game had more to offer than most survival games I've played. Unless you have ROG you're missing out on a lot of content. Don't Starve is far from forgiving, at times you might feel the developers had an evil laugh when coming up with ways to kill us helpless survivors. Don't Starve ROG feels like vanilla to me now, playing Don't Starve itself is not enough to give the game its justice, in my opinion. Don't Starve has a lot of depth, if you're more than just a casual there are so many different things to do on this game besides survive year one. (If you can make it past summer) I do wish, however, Klei put more effort into end game (other than caves OFC) I also feel SW is lacking as an expansion but all in all the price for this game in general feels awfully low for something so wonderful, I would've paid a lot more. If you don't like surviving on your own make sure you give DST a try, the community is great, I prefer Don't Starve over Don't Starve Together but that's just my cup of tea. PS, too the noobs, if you're sceptic due to one death causing your world to be erased, there are items you can craft or things you can find in order to have several lives, not only that, but also mods. The mod community for this game is HUGE, if you ever find yourself bored or feel like you need the game to be a little easier, you could try using mods. Some mods completely change Don't Starve, some make the game easier by adding items and characters, or tweaking things, other mods make the game harder. Don't Starve is a great game and the developers are fantastic and helpful.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
Product received for free
												Gather resources, build weapons, cook food, kill mobs ... sounds like Minecraft eh?That's where the similarities end. This game can be brutal as everything in this game will kill you ... I mean everything!!!Bees ... kill you!Spiders ... kill you!Hounds ... kill you!Horny Beefalo ... kill you!Insanity ... kills you!Hunger ... kills you!Darkness ... kills you!Even winter ... yep, you guessed it, winter kills you as well!If you like survival games and the Tim Burton style graphics, you'll love this game! However, you may find the game challenging and a little frustrating at first until you start to find your way. Don't let this put you off because as soon as you find your way you will immediately find yourself addicted and telling yourself "just one more day then i'll switch off I promise" only to find yourself playing through at least another 10 days ... well, if you survive that long.My tips for getting started:- Explore anywhere and everywhere but find a good base within 5 days if possible ... pigmen are your friend and so are Beefalo (just not when horny!) so pick somewhere nearby- Gather resources as quick as you can and when you think you have enough, collect more ... you'll NEVER have enough!!!- Always make sure you have the ability to make fire, and- Get a weapon ... you never know when the first attack is coming.Remember folks, winter is coming (as well as a lot of angry mobs) so be prepared ... and whatever you do, Don't Starve!

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												IT'S NOT MINECRAFTThe name of the game is really deceiving as starving is one of many ways to die in this game. I'd like to point out here I was expecting something like old Horde game - you stay in a camp, build your defences during the day, defend at night and reap your rewards.It was not the case as instead the developers gave me a game about survival and exploration. I have to say that second "X" part is really crucial for the game, as in early stages you will starve or freak out if you don't collect a lot of food, branches, some little stones that help you start a campfire. This game makes you watch out not only for your hit points but hunger level and serenity as well. Strange things happen if you become insane.Gameplay also brings you back to point'n'click adventure games where you had to find out what can be combined with what. Here it's similiar, it's trial and error with a bit of punishment, but keep in mind: this game is not an extreme hardcore self-destructive masterpiece. The learning curve isn't any steep. It's just a pleasure.As the days go by you learn new things, which gives you a lot of satisfaction. Surviving more and more days also gives you that feeling of progress, because there are new characters to unlock (with different abilities and stats).The downside to this game is that it's kinda cryptic at times and thanks to random generators you can either be in a very good starting position or a very bad one, but usually it doesn't go as far as spawning you next to a lvl 9001 mob which one-hits you.I can recommend this game. I'm not exactly a fan of survive, craft and explore games, but it still gave me some nice memories and I will certainly play it again.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												First let's just start with I've put around 10hours into this game and there is still so much I don't know and have not even touched. The best part of this game is not knowing anything about it. Running up to an animal and poking it only to have it two shot you. While you might think like a typical surival game you'll eventually get a cozy farm and endless meat and resources... Suriving is only half the battle. If you want to advance the story and actually get everything out of the game you'll need advanced items, food enough to last you a while away from base and luck in finding what you're looking for. This game has so many layers and so many ways you can play it!There is so much replay value to this game as it is rogue like and your world will be destroyed if you die and your file deleted. While there are one or two methods of gaining... basically an extra life... they're far and few between so just be prepared for lots of deaths at first. You unlock new characters as you progress and survive more and more days so each time you get different buffs ande debuffs making each experience unique and with its own challanges. Overall and amazing game with a ton of depth that is so much more than your average survival game.A huge thing is multiplayer coming out for this game. It says Summer 2015 ALPHA will be released called "Don't Starve Together." This is a major enhancement to the game. Buy it now! The devs have stated once multiplayer is fully released the price of the game will go up to $19.99 from $14.99. So grab a copy and buy one for a friend in preparation!Most importantly, don't starve!Edit 3/23/15: I'd like to add that I reccently added Reign of Giants and oh wow. You should play don't starve to death until you get bored then add the RoG dlc to it. It's a whole new game. The difficulty is much higher since you now have to deal with the rain in Spring and the heat in Summer. It feels like they've added such a huge element to the game. It honestly makes the original base game feel like it was in Early Acess or something. I won't spoil it but there new mobs, tons of new items, new playable characters and just so many new ways to die and ways to avoid dying. Get it!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												'Don't Starve' is a fun wilderness survival sandbox full of science and scary dark arts of magic. This eerily stylish hand drawn game can be easily be modded through Steam Workshop. With the options of modding, this game can be even more challenging or can played very casual and also includes 'The Screecher'  a total-conversion horror story mod made officially by Klei Entertainment. (gameplay similar to Slender)couple downsides to this game are: First time noob gameplay can be difficult because of no ingame beginning tutorial or inventory items (unless modded)Gamesaves permanently delete itself when played character dies (unless modded not to).This is a kind of game you can enjoy replaying multiple times with the many playable characters and adjustable settings on its already random map generation. I definitely recommend this to anyone who's into survival/sandbox world games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												A very good survival game.  Choose a character, each with their own little quirks and dialogue.  Explore the world, harvest food and supplies, build camps, survive attacks, discover and create crazy new things, survive the night and the hardships that come with each season, rinse and repeat.  There's good enemy variety and lots of things to discover, and you have a good amount of customization for the world before you spawn in it.  Everything from frequency of the various enemy/food spawns, to how the seasons work.  The game also comes with a Caves update (probably big enough to be a DLC) that adds an entire new biome, enemies and more, and also a mod that adds an entire other little game called The Screecher.  The DLC Reign of Giants is also worth getting, it adds quite a bit of content for it's price.  Over all, a great game.

												Don't Starve is a really simple and easy to learn survival game which I have really been enjoying. You can alter the difficulty yourself through options such as making the days longer (as it is easier to be attacked at night) and preventing the change of seasons (as your character may be effected, such as by freezing in winter), which can allow you to quickly learn the games mechanics to progress to an increased difficulty.The aim is to simply retrieve resources and craft items to aid you in surviving in the wild as long as possible, but as the world changes with each new game you allways face the challenge of exploring the new land and, if you're struggeling or need tips, the community is full of guides and advice for new players to help you survive longer.Although I have'nt played too long yet, I've still been enjoying it loads and would definately recommend this game to anyone and everyone!

content:
Posted: April 22
												Don't Starve is one of the best crafted titles in my entire library. Everything works together exceptionally well. The Burtonesque art style is great, the slightly disturbing music continually sets me on edge and the things that go bump in the night make me jump in the day. The game is one of survival. You'll be chopping wood, mining ore, farming....oh wait, this sounds familiar. It sounds like every other survival game. Except it's not. You're going to be crafting some really odd things with odd ingredients. Without spoiling it for you, there's just a lot of weird things that you can and will need to make out of wood, stone, gold, monster meat, etc.  Weapns. Armor. Boomerrangs. Crock pots. Science machines. That's the normal stuff - the weird stuff is just weird. You'll be facing creatures that are cartoonish nightmares. You're going to explore a game world that's quite original and of course, randomly generated with each start.And you're going to die. A lot. In fact, Don't Starve isn't a game. It's a death simulator.You'll die of starvation.You'll die of exposure.You'll die from bees.You'll die from walking trees.You'll die from ostrich-looking things.You'll die from your beefalos in rutting season.You'll die from things that go bump in the night.You'll die because you went insane.You'll die by spiders. You'll die by a dozen other things.And maybe, you might just starve.It's a survival game and there's no saving, so one mistake and you'll be restarting again from scratch. I generally hate that and avoid games that require restarts. Yet I keep playing Don't Starve. It's the favorite game in my library that I truly, completely suck at playing. I'm terrible and yet I have a good time.This is one that no gamer should be without.PS - Note that there are a couple of expansions for this. I never picked them up because they make the game harder and I don't need the help dying.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
												The biggest thing I like about this, is that you can never become an untouchable killer - you are always vulnerable so that it stays a survival game no matter how long you play. You can go insane to get killed by creatures of your mind, seemingly harmless animals can kill you in 5 seconds when grouped together, packs of hounds can come out of nowhere, walrus hunting parties will actively seek you out in the winter, you can freeze to death if you don't have warm clothes or fire, the night will kill you, you can starve, trees will come to life randomly, and there is no escape from the dreaded Deerclops.Lovely music, great art style (demented Dr. Seuss), large emphasis on survival, and a great developer that actively adds new content every month (see: Mojang's dumbassery).One thing I don't like is that you'll reach a certain point where you'll feel like you've seen and done everything, but this point comes after 80 hours in a single world.8/10

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Review of Don't Starve : Survival games are somewhat my thing, even though i am not good at them, i manage and enjoy playing them!Most survival games are repetitive, like the same world/maps...etc, But not Don't Starve, it is a pandora's box, each gameplay is not the same!The survival in this game is based off 3 thingI) Hunger : it is obvious that a survival game without a hunger meter is no survival game, in this game, there are two ways to get food :1\Hunting2\ planting II) Health : every game has this so there's really no point in explaining!III) Sanity : This is what made the game challenging, you have to keep yourself sane, that is by many ways, but the only one i've discovered is gathering flowers!So let's recap the whole thing : + Single player ( there's a multiplayer version too will be free when you get the game at this time )+ Workshop ( mods )+ Art Style (so you do not have to worry about needing a killing machine PC to play this game)+ Actual working DLC ( Adds a few monters and stuff, so it's worth it to improve the gameplay, but i strongly suggest you get the DLC when you get truly bored from the game )+ Replayable ( since each gameplay is not the same )+ Not a slight bug in sight= Fair XP system+ Many vanilla Characters that differ in skills!So that's a 9/10 i suggest you get it!

content:
Posted: January 24
												I bought this game a couple of years ago and since then have notched up close to 1000 hours after probably a break of six months or so, I felt drawn back recently.  For those who don't know, DS comes in essentially four formats - vanilla (Original DS), Reign of Giants - more challenges more environmental hazards, DS Together (Multiplayer) and Shipwrecked.  DS is a quirky and fun survivalist game, the Tim Burton style graphics are part of the significant charm of Don't Starve.  Arriving in a world with nothing, you must forage, build a base camp, hunt, trap, fish and farm... all the time exploring whilst preparing for battle with the bosses and the harsh weather conditions of the next seasons whilst trying to keep the nightmares away.  There are multiple characters to play as, having different strengths and weaknesses and their own unique charm. There are many different ways to play this game, you can be an animal lover, just living off what you can farm, or hunt down the various animals in game for a meatier diet.  You can have a central base or live a more nomadic lifestyle with perhaps smaller satalite bases dotted around the world.  There is an adventure mode and also the ability to decamp and travel to a newly generated world when you get bored of your current one.  Since the launch of DS shipwrecked it is now possible to link a DS Reign of Giants world to a Shipwrecked world, allowing you the ability to world hop back and forth and enjoy two different worlds within one game.The world is extensive, and comes with significant customisation options to allow you to design bespoke worlds to suit your game play, in addition to this the modding community have gone to town with this game, providing all kinds of bolt on mods including additional bosses/beasts and characters for gamers to enjoy.  When I stumbled across this beauty on a Youtube video, I knew immediately that I wanted it.  I died so many times in the first few weeks and I remember the first time I made it to day 21 in DS and the start of Winter, only to spend a pitiful 2 days by the fire with no warm clothing and no means to make it far enough to find the resources to make the clothing... cue another frustrating death.  Fortunately, one of the best parts of this game is that starting over is as engaging as being 100 + days in, the battle against time to prepare for what's to come, the flexibility of world hopping when this world becomes a chore or over run with spider queens or stripped of resources.... The thought that has gone into DS is brilliant, its a game that is gripping, fun and challenging.  Don't be fooled though by its cute quirky graphics... you will die lots, you will laugh, cry, threaten to throw your computer through the window... and you will love it.  It really is a game that will provide endless hours of ammusment. I can highly reccomend.

I wasn't expecting much, but it really is fun.Update @111hrsI can still easily spend all day playing this game and I still haven't mastered it! Half the time Im just fighting for survival that I can't get to explore the caves and stuff. Haha I guess I'm just bad at the game although I have managed to survive a few 100+ day games.. I don't think my review does the game justice. Its definitely great fun but hella challenging

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Such a unique game, I've been playing this since the early access days and it was amazing to see how it evolved, this is the way all Early Access should be managed. The game was always highly playable but evolved into a completely different beast as it neared release, constantly adding, improving and refining content so that each update made the game feel fresh.There's nothing else on the market quite like it, it's not just the tone and aesthetic that differentiate this from other survival games.  Don't Starve is a unique, fun, highly replayable experience that everybody should try, and hopefully it's only going to be improved by the upcoming multiplayer patch.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Is this game worth £11 you may ask? Silly question, of course! Inclusing the DLC too, this game is a bundle of amazingness. Don't starve is , if not, on it's way to becoming the best gaming experience around. The fact you get dropped into a completely random world full of so many things that can kill you is so much fun. Of course the main objective is to not starve, but there are so many other obstacles to overcome, and so many ways to do just that. Don't starve is an amazing game that has taken up around 100 hours of my time, and soon to be much, much more. It will soon be multiplayer, so being able to experience all the dangers, problems and sucesses but with some company is something to look forward to.If you do not have patience, then this game probably isn't the best idea. You start off with mainly grass and wood, but as the game flows on, you can be speeding around with a cane, a top hat and some turkey dinner! What could be better? This game just offers such a thrill. The fact it also has great replayability, with other characters and that you can edit your worlds however you like, making it more difficult or easy, or even install some mods made by the fabulous people in the Steam Don't Starve workshop!Overall, if you have some spare time, a bit of money and are looking for a good, fun game, then I definately recommend this one.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Don't Starve harnesses all of the successful elements of other sandbox survival games and tweeks them to create an atmosphere that is unsettling, urgent, and charming all at the same time. Overall, the game is very well executed. The world the game is set in is at first very brutal, very unforgiving, and there is little-to-none tutorialization. When you eventually start to gain a foothold, the experience can be extremely rewarding. Character perk sets and the ability to customize the world generation and cycles add lots of replay value.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This game is plenty of fun delivered in a highly stylised fashion. There's more depth than you first expect; the game can be somewhat difficult and unforgiving at times, but it's always enjoyable.The only thing I'd recommend is to take it slow; don't rush in expecting to kill everything in sight and survive simply by stabbing and punching stuff. You need to build yourself up first before you can take on the big game.On top of that, the game has a good modding community; everything from new items, to tweaks to game mechanics to make things far easier or much harder, new fan-made characters and even total conversions (the base game comes with an official surivival horror themed TC).Overall, Don't Starve is well worth the money.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Combining the aspects of survival, adventure and sandbox into one game full of mystery and wonder makes this well worth playing. Since every world you play in is completely randomised, the adventure never stops as you explore, fight and survive as you delve deeper to find every little thing to do and uncover. So, if anyone out there is up for a good challenge, then Don't Starve is the one for you. Plus, with the Reign Of Giants DLC coming out soon, you can be sure to be surprised and running for your life as you discover what this game has in store for you...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												My review is based on all expansions, not really vanilla. I was attracted to this game due to its art style and cute little Chester. Little did I know this artsy survival game had more to offer than most survival games I've played. Unless you have ROG you're missing out on a lot of content. Don't Starve is far from forgiving, at times you might feel the developers had an evil laugh when coming up with ways to kill us helpless survivors. Don't Starve ROG feels like vanilla to me now, playing Don't Starve itself is not enough to give the game its justice, in my opinion. Don't Starve has a lot of depth, if you're more than just a casual there are so many different things to do on this game besides survive year one. (If you can make it past summer) I do wish, however, Klei put more effort into end game (other than caves OFC) I also feel SW is lacking as an expansion but all in all the price for this game in general feels awfully low for something so wonderful, I would've paid a lot more. If you don't like surviving on your own make sure you give DST a try, the community is great, I prefer Don't Starve over Don't Starve Together but that's just my cup of tea. PS, too the noobs, if you're sceptic due to one death causing your world to be erased, there are items you can craft or things you can find in order to have several lives, not only that, but also mods. The mod community for this game is HUGE, if you ever find yourself bored or feel like you need the game to be a little easier, you could try using mods. Some mods completely change Don't Starve, some make the game easier by adding items and characters, or tweaking things, other mods make the game harder. Don't Starve is a great game and the developers are fantastic and helpful.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2013
												【好评。佳作。休闲。】画面风格给8分，卡通但是丰富的画面很有意境，卡通渲染的2D动态画面给很多3D画面审美疲劳的玩家一种怀旧但是也比较清新的感觉。BGM给7分，音乐比较偏古典西洋系，和游戏主题比较切合，但是音乐听多了其实发现就那么调子不是很多，不过大部分听起来还是可以的。游戏性给8分，充满丰富自由度和有趣的生存主题让人容易一口气玩很久【“别饿死”这个主题是否会想起贝爷呢~？】，时间流逝系统会让玩家更好理解游戏里主角的目的，多样化的道具合成与材料采集系统也让本游戏充满了RPG要素。总评：近期小游戏里不可多得的一款优质小品级游戏。

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I strongly recommend this game.  Reminds me of Minecraft's first few minutes/hours where you're scraping to stay alive, but this is harder, and more rewarding, minus the building for the most part.  The art style is great, very atmospheric and fun to watch.  Though no in-game instruction is given, the difficulty of picking up on how things work isn't bad, after a couple deaths, you'll know how to progress through the first few days.  That's my one gripe, dying starts you over, with no save game, it automatically deletes it for you.  This lends urgency to your quest to survive, which I like, but the first 3 days or so take half an hour, and there's not much variation in during that time, so it starts to feel a little repetitive.  But after that, there's tons of cool stuff, so it's a minor annoyance.  Also, to be fair, I wouldn't have to play those first three days so many times if I'd just follow the direction, "Don't Starve"

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Don't Starve has tons of item crafting, starving, dying, and "what the hell?" moments. Can be difficult at times, especially your first time playing it. If you want a more lenient and forgiving experience, there are plenty of mods in the workshop. If you want a more difficult and "hardcore" time, there are in game settings and mods to change those as well. There are more than a few different characters you can play as, each with their own abilities and weaknesses, after you unlock them. With a plethora of items, survival strategies, creatures to kill and eat (or get eaten by), this is a great survival game. It has plenty of replay value, and if you put the time and patience into it, it can be a very rewarding experience.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I wasn't too sure about this game when I first saw it.  Then I saw the pocket edition for my phone and decided that I would give it a try.   It took all of 5 minutes for me to realize that I HAD to have this on my PC.  I bought the bundle of the original game,  Reign of Giants, and Shipwrecked. I cannot put this game away.   I think it's totally possible that this game got its title not because of the starvation that can happen in the game but the starvation that can happen to you in the real world when you start playing this game!  I love the exploration that this game puts you through.   I have resisted the urge to watch videos or get tips online because the "not knowing what's going to happen next" aspect really adds to the experience.   Please do yourself a favor and buy this game.   It's well worth the price for the intense HOURS of fun,  stress, frustration, and obsession that you will experience while playing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												A very good survival game.  Choose a character, each with their own little quirks and dialogue.  Explore the world, harvest food and supplies, build camps, survive attacks, discover and create crazy new things, survive the night and the hardships that come with each season, rinse and repeat.  There's good enemy variety and lots of things to discover, and you have a good amount of customization for the world before you spawn in it.  Everything from frequency of the various enemy/food spawns, to how the seasons work.  The game also comes with a Caves update (probably big enough to be a DLC) that adds an entire new biome, enemies and more, and also a mod that adds an entire other little game called The Screecher.  The DLC Reign of Giants is also worth getting, it adds quite a bit of content for it's price.  Over all, a great game.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												(Experience: unlocked 7 out of 9 characters)(Time spent: 22 hours at the moment)(Bought price: Gift from friend)Don't Starve - and its DLC Reign of Giants - is a spectacular survival game that definitely nails the 'see-how-long-you-can-survive' aspect. The amount of craftable stuff keeps every run fresh and fun. This includes: weapons and armour to fend off monsters, firepit and crock pot to cook your meals, science machine and lightning rod to extend your survivability, and so much more!This is a game that tests how well you budget your time, Each day consists of a day and night cycle. By day, you can harvest food and materials but by the time night comes around you'll find yourself having to cook enough food to feed your stomache. And, if you manage to survive your first day, you get to repeat the whole process all over again, and thus, it tests how long you can live as long as you Don't Starve.Bottomline: This is a game that you should ABSOLUTELY try out, if just to see why it is so popular among many fans.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I always wanted to play in survival game where EVERYTHING CAN KILL YOU! :DDied by:- my own weapon? - CHECKED!- my own tools? - CHECKED!- my laziness? - CHECKED!- my stupidity? - CHECKED!...and that is only the beginning of nightmare you going to face.Lets go deeper, shall we? What may kill you in big bad world?:- bunnies? - CHECKED!- flowers? - CHECKED!- trees? - CHECKED!- bees? - THEY WILL DESTROY YOU!- penguins? - THEY WILL OBLITERATE YOU!...and that is only the top of the whole mountain, you will spend alot before you discover all ways to die.After...- tens of hours spent in the game,- hundreds of slained monsters,- thousands of gathered materials,... I am still on the Day 1. Yep! Totally worth it!Great game. It has very nice art style, and music. It is gameplay wise, it may seem like other "survival" games out there, but this one is really different. On the first look, you may think "Oh damm.. it is a Minecraft copy", but that opinion is far from truth. On conceptual layer they are both simillar to each other, but on the gameplay leyer they are completely different. They got completely different priorities expected from a player.My Walkthrough Guide:


DS: 1st Year - Walkthrough Guide for RoG + Shipwrecked! 
A Guide for Don't Starve
By: 𝕰𝖓𝖑𝖎𝖌𝖍𝖙𝖎𝖆

			This is a picture based walkthrough guide. Each page representing different season in the game. Each has some loose tips and milestones which you will eventually need to pass or fail. The guide is done in calendar form.

												You're dropped into a world with no tutorial, no narration, no guidebook.  Simply click on things, find out what they do, combine them with other things, and LEARN.  This game is brilliant in its simplicity and depth.  With each death, you learn a little bit more about how to survive for longer.  My only complaint is that once you figure out how to survive, the game can stagnate and become rather dull.  Sure, you can make up your own endgame goals, but I wish there was better endgame content.

Posted: May 7, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. You get thrown into the world with absolutely no real tutorials, just the challenge to try to not starve to death, or die from insanity. A tutorial is honeslty not needed though. You can quickly learn the basics through trial and error, exploring new combinations of actions. The ui layout is simple, you have various characters to choose from and even a short minimod available if you choose, which is awesome even for how short it is. I originally saw this on a game stream a friend was watching and had to play it. I am not sure if this still works, but I was able to take my game key and register it within a chrome app so I can even play quick games in my chrome browser at no extra cost. Amazing replay value.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												This is basically the premier "survival game", and barring a few classic roguelikes it is also the premier randomly generated game. It owes these high honors to its extremely long development and constant updates, bugfoxes, and balance patches. It's important for a randomly generated game to have a significant amount of content in order to keep replays fresh and exciting; I'm sure it was for this reason that the developers did not stop when the game was merely "adequate". My only complaint is the occasionally inaccurate diablo-style controls that occasionally force the player to learn some strange workarounds. In conclusion if you're not Not Starving yet why aren't you Not Starving?
