content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												I'm a big minecraft fan, especially playing survival game types. Unfortunately, I have a big issue with minecraft and survival games - it's too damn easy! It's too easy to make impervious shelters, stockpile food, and there arent any mobs that are dangerous if you're cautious and attentative. It's really hard to make the game difficult while still playable, so I've been looking desperately for other options.Don't Starve addresses many of the issues I mentioned above - shelter is hard to build (and never impervious/safe), food can't be easilt stockpiled (it spoils!! Woo!), and enemies can be VERY deadly, even when you are prepared. The seasons are also great in that they impact food availability and hot/cold can do you physical harm. So many great mechanics!Only downside is the game is currently only single player, but they are currently working on Don't Starve Together, which I'm super excited for.In short, if you like survival games but want a more challenging environment, check this game out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												At first I had thought Don't Starve would be easy, but I soon found out I was way wrong when a tree suddenly turned into a giant monster and murdered me on Day 17. I honestly was not expecting that. That bad experience was not in vain, though. Now I know in my future lives not to chop trees at dawn (seriously, don't). This is a good example of how you must learn from your experiences in order to do well in this game. The only way to succeed is by trial and error, and although it can be extremely frustrating when you lose everything, that is kind of what makes the game fun; knowing such a fate is possible puts you on edge. Also, the mod support is amazing. Getting new mods is literally 3 clicks away, and you can then easily enable/disable them from a convenient menu at the main screen. This is truely a great survival game so buy it if you're in to that kind of stuff, and good luck.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												There is so much to do. There is too much to do. Not enough time. I'm going to waste my life on this game. Maximum I've lasted is 30 days. Either winter or summer, I have not been able to survive. Summer burns everything in its path. Winter is kinda ok, you just need a thermal stone and rabbit earmuffs or beefalo coats.I love the way the map is randomized every time. That way I don't mind beginning anew each time.The game is incredibly difficult. I wonder how many people have actually beaten adventure mode.Frogs and spiders don't attack each other. Or so I found. Thumb rule is to expose an attacking enemy (spiders, bats, frogs) to a non-attacking enemy (beefalo, bees, pigs) while you run around and collect their drops.Cons - no tutorial. That sort of undermines the value of unique items. We store them but we never get around to realizing what they are meant to do. Unless you build those prehestihilitator things.- pixelated graphics at close-up. Maybe it's just the settings. But I can't make out if it reads 12 stones needed or 2.- at default settings, not all characters are present on every map. Not that I've ever explored the whole map. But sometimes, some resources are really scarce. Buy the game. Support the developers. And remember, it's not just Don't Starve. It's Don't Get Hit, Don't Stay in Dark, Don't Eat Mushrooms, Don't nay NEVER Attack Creatures in Groups, Don't Stand Idle, Don't Stop Collecting Twigs, Grass and Rocks, Don't er Do Plant Trees.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game is one of the best games i have ever played that is a survival game. The main protagonist is a mad scientist called Wilson who gets sucked into a world, where he (you) have to survive by killing animals for their fur to make clothes for the winter and meat for not starving and pick, garden vegetables for not starving too... and you can make weapons, staffs (magical things), traps, armor and other really cool stuff to survive...The map in this game is random however you chose between small, medium and HIGH (size for the map) but it's nature. A lot of trees, water, flowers, fields and swamps. But be aware you are not alone... there are monsters and wild animals in this game that might not be so friendly as they look like... and you have to build a fire before night comes, because if you don't... shadow monsters will kill you in the darkness without you seeing it coming...And actually you don't always have to play as the main character you can play as other characters once you unlocked them... and you can download other characters at the workshop... but the original characters for this game always have names that starts at the letter "w" except the last character in the list...It's an amazing game with amazing graphics (cartoon graphics) ,amazing music, amazing story, amazing experience, amazing concept and amazing everything!!! :) 10/10 ...But i recommend you buying this game for ps4 (if you have one) because it has a lot of better control for the gamepad then.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												A 2D Game for All Hardcore Survivors. This game is a strange one. It can be considered as "creative" due to its "how to survive the wilderness" concept, but it can also be an well-written script based game. Don't Starve has many mods that allows you to explore and add a bit more into the game. It is a great game and you should buy it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												I love this game!  This is a survival game in every essense of the word. In a world where you can die at one simple mistake, it really embodies a true survival experience. The amount of sheer content is enough to pick up this game alone. With randomly generated worlds, many characters that change the way you play, a wide assortment of resources that i'm sure i haven't found all of yet, a great art design, a living, breathing world everytime you boot up a map, caves, ruins, a huge and complex crafting assortment, a story mode, multiplayer being put in after early access of DST, customizable worlds, and one of the best modding communities, this game has an imense amount of lastability and will age extremely well.      The soundtrack is interesting but grows old. After a few hours I started listening to my own music. This is what I call a "wiki game" meaning you will have to live on the wiki if you want to have a clue on what to do. The biggest downfall of this game is the fact that to utilize most of the content, you have to be good, which goes back to the wiki.      Once you've become a grade A survivor, you will find yourself losing countless afternoons on building up your camp, testing new mods and so on. It is an amazing survival games and one of the best indie titles to come out of the past few years. You owe it to yourself not to overlook this masterpiece 10/10       Just look out for penguins......I HAD IT THAT TIME YOU SCUM!!!! AAAAGGGGGGHHHHHH!!!!!!!! Just one more try.....

												This was my first "early access" game to ever try and probably the only reason I tried a lot of duds after that. Now that it's released, I still enjoy playing it. content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												This is a really fantastic game.  I first got it on sale ages ago, but never really played it.  I finally installed it to give it a shot and was instantly sad at how bad I was.  I died within the first day.This game is built around trial and error.  You are going to be exploring randomly generated worlds and making a bajillion mistakes as you start to understand the things you need to do.I do not recommend reading the wikia about this game, as it will spoil a lot of the fun, which is just exploring and learning from your mistakes.  Reading a beginner's guide isn't a terrible thing, but I would save it until you've died about 20 times or at least made it to your first winter alone.I recommend waiting to play with the RoG expansion, although you could go ahead and buy it but just start playing the vanilla version.  Save mods and guides for after you have had a lot of fun wandering around being bad.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												This is a really fantastic game.  I first got it on sale ages ago, but never really played it.  I finally installed it to give it a shot and was instantly sad at how bad I was.  I died within the first day.This game is built around trial and error.  You are going to be exploring randomly generated worlds and making a bajillion mistakes as you start to understand the things you need to do.I do not recommend reading the wikia about this game, as it will spoil a lot of the fun, which is just exploring and learning from your mistakes.  Reading a beginner's guide isn't a terrible thing, but I would save it until you've died about 20 times or at least made it to your first winter alone.I recommend waiting to play with the RoG expansion, although you could go ahead and buy it but just start playing the vanilla version.  Save mods and guides for after you have had a lot of fun wandering around being bad.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												I love this game!  This is a survival game in every essense of the word. In a world where you can die at one simple mistake, it really embodies a true survival experience. The amount of sheer content is enough to pick up this game alone. With randomly generated worlds, many characters that change the way you play, a wide assortment of resources that i'm sure i haven't found all of yet, a great art design, a living, breathing world everytime you boot up a map, caves, ruins, a huge and complex crafting assortment, a story mode, multiplayer being put in after early access of DST, customizable worlds, and one of the best modding communities, this game has an imense amount of lastability and will age extremely well.      The soundtrack is interesting but grows old. After a few hours I started listening to my own music. This is what I call a "wiki game" meaning you will have to live on the wiki if you want to have a clue on what to do. The biggest downfall of this game is the fact that to utilize most of the content, you have to be good, which goes back to the wiki.      Once you've become a grade A survivor, you will find yourself losing countless afternoons on building up your camp, testing new mods and so on. It is an amazing survival games and one of the best indie titles to come out of the past few years. You owe it to yourself not to overlook this masterpiece 10/10       Just look out for penguins......I HAD IT THAT TIME YOU SCUM!!!! AAAAGGGGGGHHHHHH!!!!!!!! Just one more try.....

												Don't starve is a great survival game that feels a bit like a darker, harder 2D version of minecraft (you need to collect, build and progress in order to stay alive). If you enjoy learning stuff the hard way and constantly improving your style of playing then this is definitely a game for you, but if you don't enjoy working hard and losing everything you built up over and over again by dying afterwards (you will always die sooner or later) then this is no game for you... Would definitely recommend this game to the more experienced and determined gamers amongst us.I had so much fun I nearly starved to death myself because I couldn't stop playing!

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												This game is a very detailed and complex game that starts out with you waking up and this man pops out of the ground. He tells you to look for some food before nightfall so, you take his advice and get up off the ground in search of flint, food, etc. It seems so simple yet it is so complex! there are many characters in the game that you DO NOT NEED TO BUY! They are all unlocked by survivng and gaining XP. This game is a very addictive game that keeps you coming back! There are also mods like Wulfe, Easter Eggs, and Bigger Stacks (my reccomendations). Check this game out and get the Reign Of Giants DLC, its really cool! So, overall, this game is a fantasy-based game that feels like Minecraft and Terraria but in a 3-D world with more things to craft, much more things to do, and many other fantasy creatures out to get you like Hounds, Tallbirds, Spiders, etc. So, check this game out! And are you good enough to not Starve?

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												There are plenty of videos out there showing game play, but I think the best recommendation for this game is how much new stuff you still learn about the game on almost every playthrough. At first, the game appears impossible and that everything is out to kill you. While not impossible, most things are out to kill you, and survival is using it to your advantage. Then, as you learn what is important, when is the best time to do things, how to do them, where to go (or not go), and why you should, the game becomes "easier".Make no mistake, on my current playthrough, I am almost to Day 200 and the game is certainly not easier. In fact, some things have gotten more difficult, and death is around every turn. However, this is what makes the game so great.Then, to top it all off, there is Adventure Mode, which is accessed via an object in the Sandbox Mode (where all games start). While Sandbox Mode could be a full game by itself, Adventure Mode is like checking "Hardcore" as you have to take everything you know from Sandbox and use it to make it through all the Chapters (a feat I have yet to accomplish). These Chapters ramp up certain challenges, limit a random resource, etc. Fortunately, this is where the game does let up, as you can repeat Adventure Mode without consquences because you "regain consciousness" upon death in your Sandbox Mode to try again. The best part? The Chapters and levels are regenerated every restart, so you cannot memorize the maps, making it truly an "adventure".tl;dr You want a challenging game that makes you think, and punishes your every mistake? Get this game.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												After watching trailers and several pictures provided, Don’t Starve’s bettlejuice inspiration, alluring soundtrack, and hand-drawn adorable cast of characters to the wilderness the itself, it begged me to play it. Aside its show and tell features, Don’t Starve truly emphasis the survival genre. Survive however you want to survive: live off the land, wield dark magic, rely on old school hunting tactics, or take your enemies head on to a glorious death. Be prepared for anything and stay well stocked, because if you’re not, the telltale of winter will make survival become much harder. If you find the game too easy, too hard or isn't offering the challenge you want, no problem. There’s plenty of options for you to customize your own world, however you see fit.The asking price is fair or even spot on with its abundance of content and uniqueness makes this survival game truly stand out. Search no further for I utmost recommend this game for those who love survival and looking for uniqueness. The Reign of Giants (RoG) DLC made the game even more content, stronger, dangerous and funnier survival experience.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is amazing. The style is incredibly cool, the music is great, and the gameplay even better. I cannot find the words to accurately summarise the level of awesome Don't Starve is, it's just absolutely brilliant, in so many ways. As you get no tutorial, no hints (apart from the obvious - don't starve!), it is a game of figuring stuff out at first, and there are so many things to expore, find, and craft! Seeing as you can customise just about everything in your world before you start a game, there are endless possibilities when it comes to difficulty, and not to mention, the dreaded Adventure mode which will make you want to gouge your eyes out with a rusty spoon and throw them at the treeguards while you scream with the fury of a thousand suns. If you like survival, base building, hillarious puns, exploring, crafting, and not having a game tell you exactly what to do at all times - Don't Starve is for you. 10/10 in my book!...Apart from the treeguards. F*** you, treeguards.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												I'm a big minecraft fan, especially playing survival game types. Unfortunately, I have a big issue with minecraft and survival games - it's too damn easy! It's too easy to make impervious shelters, stockpile food, and there arent any mobs that are dangerous if you're cautious and attentative. It's really hard to make the game difficult while still playable, so I've been looking desperately for other options.Don't Starve addresses many of the issues I mentioned above - shelter is hard to build (and never impervious/safe), food can't be easilt stockpiled (it spoils!! Woo!), and enemies can be VERY deadly, even when you are prepared. The seasons are also great in that they impact food availability and hot/cold can do you physical harm. So many great mechanics!Only downside is the game is currently only single player, but they are currently working on Don't Starve Together, which I'm super excited for.In short, if you like survival games but want a more challenging environment, check this game out.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												I went into this game thinking it would be something like Minecraft or Terraria.Boy, was I wrong.A survival/crafting game that mixes together crafting, survival, and psychological horror (in a sense), this game was a refreshing change of pace from the world of "straight-forward sandboxes."  The world is alive with all sorts of flora and fauna to gather and hunt, but not all of it will just accept their fate of becoming your next meal.Will you be able to survive the purgatorial landscape as you struggle to live on through the night?  Or will you succumb to the horrors of the night that will turn the hunter into the hunted?Overall, I give this game 5 live-saving fires out of 5

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												At first I had thought Don't Starve would be easy, but I soon found out I was way wrong when a tree suddenly turned into a giant monster and murdered me on Day 17. I honestly was not expecting that. That bad experience was not in vain, though. Now I know in my future lives not to chop trees at dawn (seriously, don't). This is a good example of how you must learn from your experiences in order to do well in this game. The only way to succeed is by trial and error, and although it can be extremely frustrating when you lose everything, that is kind of what makes the game fun; knowing such a fate is possible puts you on edge. Also, the mod support is amazing. Getting new mods is literally 3 clicks away, and you can then easily enable/disable them from a convenient menu at the main screen. This is truely a great survival game so buy it if you're in to that kind of stuff, and good luck.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												This is what I'm talking about. I love games that force you to make hard decisions about what your doing next in it. Don't starve is the perfect example of how games should make you consider almost every action you take. Theres almost no story, no tutorial, and no hand holding. You make the story as you go along. You make life and death decisions every step of the way, and if you mess up? BOOM your dead, game over, please insert two quarters to continue. This is how games should be made. I've faced more indecision and planned farther ahead in this game then Banner Saga, Mass Effect, Dragon Age or any other game that touts its "branching storyline". Theres ALMOST no check points, no reloads, and no do overs. And If you do manage to figure out how to respawn, theres penalties for doing so. Everytime you come back to life, your overall health, sanity, and hunger decrease. This game is amazing, and true to the Golden Era of gaming. Play it.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Don't Starve is a semi-3D survival adventure. A witty, amusing style takes over this game and it has its ups and downs. On one hand, it has roguelike characteristics (permadeath) and just tosses the player into the world. The games settings can be altered per playthrough, but judging it on the normal difficulty, I can say it's certainly a challenge. I'd recommend it for people who love to be on edge. The game constantly throws new challenges at you, and only the most obvious mistakes like staying in the dark or poking a beehive, will outright kill you, or close to it. While it's not known for being difficult, the learning curve is steady. Survive though, and it's strangely satisfying. Recommended for those who like challenge, learning experiences, crafting, exploration. It's as adventure as it gets.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The graphics are unique and fascinating, personally I love them. Some people even fear the game a bit because the graphics are unsettling to them which I personally just think would only add to the experience of being in a new, hostile world.There are tons of mods for the game if you'd ever get bored of it, a large variety of characters and hours of playtime.The game at first seems real frustrating but in a way that you'd want to give it another shot and avoid what killed you.Also the amount of pets and styles of pets are pretty fun. I personally love Chester most, a treasure chest looking dog creature that follows you around and lets you store things in his mouth.Whenever you seem that the world has dried out and you are sure to die unless you find something that will rejuvinate everyting, it is time to head into the caves. But you risk your life to the new enemies that await you there.It's not ONLY survival as far as you can go, there is for example the Adventure Mode.The different mechanics to the characters and different stats for them make it seem like you're playing another game since you'll have to play the game a completely different way if you're to gain an advantage, so when you've unlocked everything you still might not know what character it is you want to use. None is better than the rest.If you are looking for a realistic game, then this is probably not for you.If you're looking for a game to spend quite a lot of time in and see new types of enemies and like games that look pretty (Perhaps such as Sworcery and Bastion) then this is something you should give a shot.

												Don't Starve is a really simple and easy to learn survival game which I have really been enjoying. You can alter the difficulty yourself through options such as making the days longer (as it is easier to be attacked at night) and preventing the change of seasons (as your character may be effected, such as by freezing in winter), which can allow you to quickly learn the games mechanics to progress to an increased difficulty.The aim is to simply retrieve resources and craft items to aid you in surviving in the wild as long as possible, but as the world changes with each new game you allways face the challenge of exploring the new land and, if you're struggeling or need tips, the community is full of guides and advice for new players to help you survive longer.Although I have'nt played too long yet, I've still been enjoying it loads and would definately recommend this game to anyone and everyone!

content:
Posted: April 22
												Don't Starve is one of the best crafted titles in my entire library. Everything works together exceptionally well. The Burtonesque art style is great, the slightly disturbing music continually sets me on edge and the things that go bump in the night make me jump in the day. The game is one of survival. You'll be chopping wood, mining ore, farming....oh wait, this sounds familiar. It sounds like every other survival game. Except it's not. You're going to be crafting some really odd things with odd ingredients. Without spoiling it for you, there's just a lot of weird things that you can and will need to make out of wood, stone, gold, monster meat, etc.  Weapns. Armor. Boomerrangs. Crock pots. Science machines. That's the normal stuff - the weird stuff is just weird. You'll be facing creatures that are cartoonish nightmares. You're going to explore a game world that's quite original and of course, randomly generated with each start.And you're going to die. A lot. In fact, Don't Starve isn't a game. It's a death simulator.You'll die of starvation.You'll die of exposure.You'll die from bees.You'll die from walking trees.You'll die from ostrich-looking things.You'll die from your beefalos in rutting season.You'll die from things that go bump in the night.You'll die because you went insane.You'll die by spiders. You'll die by a dozen other things.And maybe, you might just starve.It's a survival game and there's no saving, so one mistake and you'll be restarting again from scratch. I generally hate that and avoid games that require restarts. Yet I keep playing Don't Starve. It's the favorite game in my library that I truly, completely suck at playing. I'm terrible and yet I have a good time.This is one that no gamer should be without.PS - Note that there are a couple of expansions for this. I never picked them up because they make the game harder and I don't need the help dying.

content:
Posted: January 24
												I bought this game a couple of years ago and since then have notched up close to 1000 hours after probably a break of six months or so, I felt drawn back recently.  For those who don't know, DS comes in essentially four formats - vanilla (Original DS), Reign of Giants - more challenges more environmental hazards, DS Together (Multiplayer) and Shipwrecked.  DS is a quirky and fun survivalist game, the Tim Burton style graphics are part of the significant charm of Don't Starve.  Arriving in a world with nothing, you must forage, build a base camp, hunt, trap, fish and farm... all the time exploring whilst preparing for battle with the bosses and the harsh weather conditions of the next seasons whilst trying to keep the nightmares away.  There are multiple characters to play as, having different strengths and weaknesses and their own unique charm. There are many different ways to play this game, you can be an animal lover, just living off what you can farm, or hunt down the various animals in game for a meatier diet.  You can have a central base or live a more nomadic lifestyle with perhaps smaller satalite bases dotted around the world.  There is an adventure mode and also the ability to decamp and travel to a newly generated world when you get bored of your current one.  Since the launch of DS shipwrecked it is now possible to link a DS Reign of Giants world to a Shipwrecked world, allowing you the ability to world hop back and forth and enjoy two different worlds within one game.The world is extensive, and comes with significant customisation options to allow you to design bespoke worlds to suit your game play, in addition to this the modding community have gone to town with this game, providing all kinds of bolt on mods including additional bosses/beasts and characters for gamers to enjoy.  When I stumbled across this beauty on a Youtube video, I knew immediately that I wanted it.  I died so many times in the first few weeks and I remember the first time I made it to day 21 in DS and the start of Winter, only to spend a pitiful 2 days by the fire with no warm clothing and no means to make it far enough to find the resources to make the clothing... cue another frustrating death.  Fortunately, one of the best parts of this game is that starting over is as engaging as being 100 + days in, the battle against time to prepare for what's to come, the flexibility of world hopping when this world becomes a chore or over run with spider queens or stripped of resources.... The thought that has gone into DS is brilliant, its a game that is gripping, fun and challenging.  Don't be fooled though by its cute quirky graphics... you will die lots, you will laugh, cry, threaten to throw your computer through the window... and you will love it.  It really is a game that will provide endless hours of ammusment. I can highly reccomend.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Don't Starve is a semi-3D survival adventure. A witty, amusing style takes over this game and it has its ups and downs. On one hand, it has roguelike characteristics (permadeath) and just tosses the player into the world. The games settings can be altered per playthrough, but judging it on the normal difficulty, I can say it's certainly a challenge. I'd recommend it for people who love to be on edge. The game constantly throws new challenges at you, and only the most obvious mistakes like staying in the dark or poking a beehive, will outright kill you, or close to it. While it's not known for being difficult, the learning curve is steady. Survive though, and it's strangely satisfying. Recommended for those who like challenge, learning experiences, crafting, exploration. It's as adventure as it gets.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2013
												Don't starve is 2d survival game with a gorgeous art style that looks like Tim Burton movies have turned into cartoons. There is a sandbox mode, where you try to survive as long as you can, as well as an adventure mode with a minimal story. There is also a wide variety of crafting (as well as cooking) which is neatly organized into different tiers.While the game's purpose is quite simple -not to starve- you get no handholding whatsoever. Your character is stranded in an unknown world, where you need to figure out what to do in order to survive. This can result in several deaths initially, as well as loads of hilarious situations which inevitably occur when you run around poking things. Don't starve is mostly unforgiving to your mistakes -which can end in permanent death- but rewards you with unlocking several characters with unique abilities, in order to spice up your gameplay. There is an option to tweak several world aspects as well, if you are looking for a more casual sandbox experience. I should also mention there are constant updates and a workshop community for this game.Definitely recommend it, if all the above are your cup of tea :)

												Don't Starve is a sandbox survival game with an unique graphic style, odd setting and challenging but rewarding gameplay. The goal is to survive as long as possible in a very hostile world. It's a tough task but it can be done if you know what you are doing. The game is usually pretty enjoyable but sometimes it can also be very frustrating.  If you like survival games, if you enjoy Tim Burton-esque artwork, or if you’re just looking for an unforgiving challenge of a game, pick up This game immediately. Pretty much everything about this game is fantastic, and you’ll undoubtedly fall in love with it.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												An insidious little game that presents itself to you in an easy to understand and play interface but has astounding depth and replay value. You will die, a lot. And with each death learn, and become better at surviving. And try again. And again. And again. When you have mastered surviving winter, giant monsters will demolish you. When you survive giant monsters, cave dwelling beasts will devour you. When you survive even those, youa re ready for Reign of Giants and Summer witll make you long for winter. And you will never be able to put this game down.Dont get this game. IT will take time away from getting through your backloig. :p

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Don't stave is a very unique game. Not only because of the gameplay, but also because of the artwork.But seriously, i really can't compare this game with any other game i have ever played.It's a survival, sandbox, building, fighting and crafting game basically.You craft your own weapons, your own tools, you can build traps to catch other animals with, you can build your own base (not a house, but a base) and try to survive pretty much.The crafting menu in this game is very organized and readily comprehensible, which is a must, especially if you play other crafting games you sometimes forget how to craft what.You can also unlock and play as other characters who all have different perks, so that's another point for the replayabilty of this game.The seasons in this game also change from spring to summer to autumn to winter (if you survive that long.)There are also different "stages." On the map there are various locations of "worm holes." When you jump into them, they teleport you to another map.I haven't seen that much from this game yet, so i can't go into too much detail, but i like what i have seen so far.I would recommend this game, especially if you like survival and crafting games. It's very unique, both gameplay and artwork-wise and there is a lot to discover. Also because the maps are always randomly generated.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Don't Starve is an addictive game that requires you to not only not starve but live through multiple challenges that constantly threaten your survival. It has wonderful artwork that creates a charming yet creepy atmosphere. It reminds me of Tim Burton's style. I love the size of the world and what you stumble across in your explorations. Artifacts (useful and not), skeletons with helpful equipment and my favorite, the Beefalo. It's great that you can tweak the game to your liking and have different characters to choose from. The characters are imaginative with their own strengths and weaknesses. I recommend this game. It's well worth it and has a lot of replay value.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 25, 2013
												This is that sort of game that'll kick you in the groin and then give you a reasurring pat...ONLY TO KICK YOU IN THE GROIN AGAIN.I hate it....Probably one of my top ten games.Don't starve is a survival game with a mixture of 2D and 3D graphics creating a 3D world filled with 2D characters,items and what not. The game will send you into the wildreness without any tips and you'll learn on from there. Don't Starve is a game that offers a lot but does it slowly so there are those who would find the first one or two hours of playing in a new save (world) boring. The most GLORIOUS thing about it is,exactly,the sheer lack of knowledge. From the first five minutes,you'll learn the basic controls on your own,but you will encounter many new things that you will have no idea what they are and the only way to learn would be to interact with them....Experiment,pick 'em up,eat them,burn them,attack them...Of course,do know that you might end up dead and....Yeah,it's that game. It's that glorious perma-death game and it was delivered very nicely.Please,just,PLEASE don't go looking for 620 kink scope try hard guides on how to be PR0 at this game as it'll just remove all the fun fo learning on your own. It is much better if the player is forced to explore and learn on their own,even if it means going through trial and error. The worlds are always randomly generated which give the game a somewhat different flavour every time you play and let's not forget the different characters with different perks which will affect your play style too.Hunt,gather and make your own camp...Then spend the nights trembling in fear next to your campfire hoping those ''things'' don't gather the wits to come near the light of your fire....And then...When all of that is done and when you think that you've survived the worst,winter comes making everything much harder to get to and,once again,changing your tactics and food rationing.Definitely a game worth playing,thouh I can only imagine this having a small Multiplayer mode. Perhaps two to four players surviving together?

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Don't let the adorable Tim Burton-style graphics and cute beefalo fool you. This is a game that wants you to die.Repeatedly.Even if you make the game easier (you can disable some of the more game ending monsters from spawning!) on your poor, weather-beaten and starving soul, you are still going to die.But you'll like it. You'll do it again and again and you may just forget you were supposed to do adventure mode and actually accomplish something other than establishing your base camp.Since purchasing this game during the summer sale, I have been completely in love with Don't Starve. The object is simple; survive. It's just that the whole surviving part isn't that simple and you'll end up killing yourself if the wildlife doesn't do that on your behalf. I guess that's what makes it so addicting. I keep learning from my mistakes and I build better farms. I get myself better armor faster and I've figured out what I failed to do in winter that kept me from surviving the next summer.It's a survival game in which you'll collect items, learn recipes, and kiss your character "good luck" as you embark on a little adventure. Do some farming! Do some exploring! Do some fighting! ...and then run for your life!The music is lovely and fits the mood from each day dawning to a change of scenery (and boss battles with trees from satan). Worth noting with the music character has an instrument that serves as a speaking voice, embodying their personalities as you learn to get along with them as you well, don't starve! Each character is unique and provides pros and cons to their playing style. Personally, I'm a fan of Willow, Wendy, and Wilson. You'll notice that each character has a name starting with the letter W and there is a much larger connection to everyone than at first glance. It's rather neat and I'll admit, I spoiled myself after I reached day thirty and died in a ball of fire.Graphics are dark and cartoony. You'll think Tim Burton or one of your favorite "edgy" and darker cartoons of the 90s that we all had as some brain junk food. It's actually rather cute and can make even the most ugly and terrifying creatures in the game look very disarming until they try to rip your head off and suck out your fluids. For this type of game and the storyline eluded to, it works. It's delightfully creepy yet you're smiling along because it's a twisted little world you're traversing in. Nothing is at all what it seems, but you can't help admire what pretty little things are there.Until they murder you.This isn't a difficult game to learn. Use the mouse and the WSDA keys to move. I tend to use both and click with the mouse to harvest or order a character to act, leaving ample time to react to things such as demonic wolves wielding fire (yes they're in this game and I'm not sure why wolves need sometimes need fire when teeth and claws were perfectly fine, but the game is called Don't Starve, not Easy Super Happy Camp Time).You'll be tempted to sometimes play this game in long marathons. While there's no work-out you'll get from your mouse or keyboard, give your eyes a break. The only sudden flashes you'll find is from in-game lightning, but this can actually be disabled before you start a new world.While you might get a jump from things coming out of the woodworks to kill you and ruin your hard work or you may feel very frustrated when you accidentally set fire to your camp and ruin about a hundred days worth of work, I still find this game to have everything I was looking for after a long time of searching. No rampaging armies. Just me and the elements as my own doom.If you've got a short temper or you dislike doing repetitive things in order to build up a catche and THEN venture forth, this probably isn't something you're going to like. For me, however? I needed this game a long time ago and I'm very ashamed I didn't get it sooner. It's my new favorite game and you'll pry it out of my cold, dead, starving fingers.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2013
												Here is my personal review of Don't StarveGame play: Don't Starve offers an immense spectrum of how to approach surviving.  Players will be able to survive the way they want to survive and discovering what works and what doesn't is part of the fun of Don't Starve.  Use the Don't Starve wiki to a minimum and learn to play the game your way.  Don't Starve can be fun for children and adults.  There is very little room Don't Starve leaves for boredom, really the only downtime I have found is those nights I get caught away from my base, which often turn out to be the scariest.Sound/Music: Not much to say here.  The sound is not annoying or appealing in any significant way.  I often turn the music down or off, as it can drown out the hounds calling.  When tired of the music  I replace with any music that I enjoy listening to at low volume.  The music is fitting and well done, but pretty repetitive after so many hours.Controls: I have now played with both keyboard/mouse and controller, I will have to admit I prefer the controller now.  There are times where I wish I had the mouse again, so there are advantages and disadvantages to both.  In a way that is unique, I usually find myself of the opinion that one method is superior to the other.  The control system shouldn't disappoint a new player or even a veteran player and the control mechanics will not leave much to be desired.Graphics: Being a 2D and stylized game, the artwork must be impressionistic to vitalize the player's cognitive reception.  Don't Starve accomplishes itself graphically with a simple approach that does not get in the way of the game's strengths.  The only part of the graphics that seem odd to me is the ocean or shore lines, but again that doesn't actually affect the game in any negative way.  Value: Currently at $15 Don't Starve is a great value.  The game is fun, appropriate for family, and has good replay value.  Also purchasing now is a good investment for Don't Starve Together which is an update coming soon that adds multi-player.  They plan to increase the price of the game by $5 when that update is live.  Likes/Dislikes:The most distinguishable ingredients of Don't Starve is the survival balance.  The game is not too hard and not too easy, yet if you feel one way or another you can modify the game world how you see fit.  I enjoy the ability to create a base, but not have it so powerful that it breaks the difficulty.  I also love that the game is a wilderness survival game and doesn't offer a house or tower to stand atop to break the threat of enemies on the ground.Little upsets I have had is the worm-holes and how you cannot enter a worm hole while being attacked; I've died like this multiple times now and still have not learned that lesson.  The need to rotate the camera is often aggravating and disorienting, but there are some remedies to that.  Conclusion:A very pronounced title that offers intimidating experiences in wilderness survival.  Don't Starve holds a key to my desire that many survival games do not.  I hope to see more of Don't Starve in the future, especially with Don't Starve Together.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I adore this game. It's a quirky survivalist game, but don't let the adorable artwork confuse you---this is not an easy game. The UI is minimal and the controls are simple, and in the beginning the learning curve isn't too steep. Find food; collect items to make a fire. Stay in the light. Not so hard, right?Until you start exploring, and you find unknown foods, unknown creatures, and unknown items. Will you eat that mushroom? Those berries? Will you touch that giantic bird thing that you've never seen before and it looks like it might be frien----NO, OH NO, DO NOT TOUCH THAT BIRD RUUUUNNNNNNNNNNN....Ahem. This is a clever and wickedly addicting survival game that will keep you on your toes. Even better, it's now multiplayer--though don't think that makes it a whole lot easier... The main game has permanent death, which I actually quite enjoy. There's something so exciting about surviving longer than any other time you've played. If you really wish you can turn that option off, however. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to find out what happens when I use a sleeping dart on that giant tree thing over there.

Cons:        - None that i can think of :)10/10 one of my favorite games!

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												A deliciously brutal game of discovery.  The main game is highly customizeable for those who want to take a pleasant camping trip, but the game offers a real sense of accomplishment for those looking for a challenge.  Every death is a lesson learned, and you'll find yourself saying "I'll just play for a couple more minutes so that I can build this or hunt that."  There are plenty of characters to be earned as well, which helps keep the experience interesting.  This is definitely a game where you must set your own goals and plan ahead; if you are the type of player who wants quests and clearly defined objectives, this is not the game for you.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Already died over 30 times. Wilson never even lived to see another day on the first game.The following characters lived for less than 10 days. As I learned more about the game, I got really hooked up with gathering items so that I can get my character to craft and eventually fighting monsters for the loot. I enjoyed looking for food sources and then cooking crockpot recipes. Figuring out how I should build my base also got me really interested more with other events that may happen in the game. Eventually I got Wilson surviving through the winter and was able to make him live for more than 100 days. Most of my playtime were done in survival mode, now I think I am ready for adventure mode.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2013
												Dont starve is one of those games that every time you play you get a little better at it and in doing so you feel an overall feeling of acheivement not seen in many games (dare i say it,it reminded me of the feeling i had playing dark souls).Very much like the classic games from FROM SOFTWARE this game throws you in at the deep end and you either sink or swim,having said that every time you die when you play next time you know a little bit more to get that little bit further and survive for that little bit longer.I have many a time played this game and yet i seem to keep being surprised by the amount of new things i keep bumping into (especially during a full moon OH THAT WAS CREEPY).I love the games that the developers made before this one (the shank games are fantastic-still remind me of the film machete though) but i think that this game is their crowning glory and will be hard for them to top.The graphics suit this game and just add to the overall experience you have whilst playing.Again this is another game that again shows up the big developers and shows that smaller developers have more more orriginality than they do (money does'nt allways mean that your game is the best and shiny graphice dont allways make good gameplay please take note all you power hungry developers).In closing i love this game and if you want a challenge you should look no further than DONT STARVE.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												The game is an original survival game. Nobody knows the full story behind it, but they put little secrets in the game so you can see a bit of the story. In the game you don't just pickup stuff and shove it in your mouth... well you can do that but you can cook the food, build a base, prepare for winter. The whole "crafting" mechanism is awesome I think. The landscape is giant so you can venture anywhere. However if you get bored in that world... you can find or create a portal wich will activate "adventure mode" wich is a little more challenging than the normal gamemode. The Adventure Mode has scenarios that will make the game harder and it has five chapters. At the end of the chapter theres the end of the game wich i think was pretty good. By the way these "screnarios" in adventure mode, you can imagine them like... in the first chapter ("King of Winter") there is always winter... wich is bad because you don't have anything warm at the start.Well that was a little review. Hope you want to play the game and experience these things. And remember, Don't Starve.(sorry my english is kinda' bad :D)

Day 157 I can jokingly recall the run where I died 3 times in a row because it was night time and Willow had lost her lighter regenerating. All around it's a great game of survival that gets addicting fast. I can play it for hours at a time or even watch others play it because it's always different. There is always new stuff to find or be killed by.

												Was running through the darkness in winter with my torch about to go out and no way of building another or making a pit. So I set the forest on fire for warmth and light. Overheated and died. 10/10But really, this is a game you cannot win. You can only survive until your inevitable death finally catches you. And it'll probably be something ridiculous compared to all the things you survived. Frogs want to kill you. Hounds want to kill you. Penguins want to kill you. You might go insane or starve or die alone in the dark. Even the things that generally don't want to kill you may decide to kill you.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Don’t Starve là 1 trò chơi sinh tồn trong vùng hoang dã đầy khoa học và phép thuật. Bạn đóng vai Wilson, một Gentleman Scientist, người bị con quỷ lừa và đưa đến một thế giới hoang dã bí ẩn. Wilson phải học cách khám phá môi trường xung quanh và các cư dân của nó nếu muốn trốn thoát và tìm được đường trở về nhà. Tiến vào một thế giới kỳ lạ, chưa được khám phá, đầy các sinh vật kỳ dị, nguy hiểm và bất ngờ. Khai thác tài nguyên để chế tạo đồ vật và các công trình phù hợp với phong cách sống của bạn. Chơi theo cách của bạn khi làm sáng tỏ những bí ẩn của vùng đất xa lạ này.✔ Sinh tồn & Khám phá thế giới:Không hướng dẫn. Không giúp đỡ. Bắt đầu bằng tay không và bắt đầu chế tạo thủ công, săn bắn, nghiên cứu, tạo trang trại và chiến đấu để tồn tại.✔ Liên tục cập nhật:Tham gia vào một cộng đồng năng động, vẫn tiếp tục giúp hình thành trò chơi khi nội dung mới được thêm vào!✔ Đồ họa đen tối và kỳ dị:Nhân vật 2D và các sinh vật kỳ lạ sống ở một thế giới 3D độc đáo.✔ Ngẫu nhiên tạo thế giới mới:Muốn có một bản đồ mới? Không vấn đề gì! Bất cứ lúc nào bạn cũng có thể tạo ra một một thế giới mới ghét bạn và muốn bạn chết.Yugen

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												On the surface, it seems like a very simple 2D game, and to be honest when I saw trailer I wasn't that interested.  However, a friend recommended it to me and after trying it, I was immediately hooked.  It has hidden layers of complexity and a charming morbid Gorey-esque aesthetic which fits perfectly into the game play.  You'll start off gathering berries and luring bunnies into your traps with carefree carrots and soon be fighting off nightmare hounds and delving into caves in search of glowberries and other things that grant you precious, precious light.  Its complexity comes slowly and its the sort of game that's as deep as you want to make it.  You can spend days and days just playing around collecting food and making the perfect camp or you can try for more challenging content in your own time by calling upon the dark arts for more powerful items.  Don't Starve, but also don't be caught in the dark, don't freeze, don't get eaten by a monoptic ruminant and most especially don't forget to build lightning rods.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												"Uncompromising" is right!  While you can customize pretty much every aspect of the game if you want to, jiggering with the default settings is for whiners, crybabies, and those who need to be fed with a spoon.I discovered this game about the same time I got into Minecraft, so the comparisons are irresistible.  However, "vidjamagame where you take materials from the wilderness to survive amid myriad threats and it's more dangerous at night" is where the similarities end.  I'll highlight a few key differences: ~ Minecraft doesn't have a sanity meter.  And unlike most games with a sanity mechanic, here your hallucinations can kill you. ~ Minecraft doesn't have a half-dozen-plus characters, each with distinct advantages and disadvantages. ~ Minecraft is about building.  Don't Starve is about surviving. ~ In Minecraft, you can safely ignore the tech tree if you're in creative mode, or even in hardcore mode if you mainly stick to the surface and concentrate on building well-lit structures.  In Don't Starve, ignoring the tech tree will get you killed in short order. ~ In Minecraft, only enemies, heights, and lava are really dangerous.  In Don't Starve, the darkness itself will kill you, winter can kill you, bees can kill you, and every few days a pack of roving hounds will spawn specifically to kill you - and yes, every pack you kill makes the next one stronger.In summary, Minecraft is an exploration and building game with wilderness survival elements; Don't Starve is a roguelike wilderness survival game with building and exploration elements.  The "roguelike" is what's key there:  high difficulty, frequent death, no backup saves, and don't forget the delightful Victorian aesthetic.  OK, I got a bit away from the "roguelike" theme at the end there.  :)If this game appeals to you at all, give it a shot.  Plus, The Screecher (a free included total conversion mod by the dev team) is the first game in a long time to make me physically jump in my chair.  It's almost an homage to Slender, but the fact that it's randomly generated (so you can't memorize the map across multiple playthroughs) and the stylized graphics really set it apart.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Imagine. You are a mad scientist, plucked from your lab and dropped in the wilderness with naught but the clothes on your back. And it's not just any normal wilderness, oh no! It's one filled with strange and dangerous creatures! Its up to you to survive, using all the natural resources available to you, as well as your own ingenuity! Just, don't forget to eat. And dont forget to pack a torch either.Don't Starve is an exercize in survival. You need to keep yourself fed to avoid starvation, you need to fight off monsters as you explore your surroundings, and whatever happens, you need to make sure you have a source of light at night. Failure at any of the aforementioned three means you die, and have to start over in an entirely new world! Don't Starve is surprisingly complex and can eat away hours of your time as you try to figure out new items to build, new food recipes to try out (that may or may not be poisonous) and new ways to help you stay alive in a hostile world! If you're an avid lover of indie games with a flair for the strange and the creepy, Don't Starve is at the top of my list for you to buy!

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Would you like a game that utterly destroys your sanity? Well, this is your game! It's Brutal difficulty will bring you to your knees, and then after, thustly chopping your head off! Let me recall my experience thus far,First game:Get in, try and collect food... enjoying my time, then suddently blackness! My character, confused, comments on the sheer darkness of the night, and then, 1 SWIPE! 2 SWIPE! Game Over!Second game:survive 6 days, and then my sanity level dropped so low, that monsters of my imagination ravaged my face off with their mighty claws and teeth!Third game: Still surviving, found a good cycle to keep steady food, so i built a small fort surrounding a science machine, and others, it rains. I notice a slight increase in frogs around me, and pay no interest. I then, later try to kill one, and by now, they have surrounded my small fort, i hit it once with a spear, and it, with its giant mallet tongue, hits me 3 times, down to 10 health! Still alive though! I retreat to my fort, when then, a lightning bolt cuts through the sky, and burns my humble home to the ground, and the ashes, blew away swiftly in the wind! SUCH A DIFFICULT GAME, it will hurt you again and again, and the challenge is compellling! i enjoy this game, because it does not hold your hand, in fact, if u try to hold its hand, it will slap you across the face, and kick you while your down. 10/10 would recommend this game, verrrrry challenging, but very fun!

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												The world of Don't Starve might first look like the one of Minecraft or Terraria, but many things are different, you can't just spend the night inside a house, looking out from a window. You are always in danger and you can't know when the worst will come and without any preparing, you'll easily get killed. You can't have infinite light sources, you need fuel and something to burn the fuel on every night. You always need to be on the lookout and get more food. You can't know when a giant monster totters to your camp and breaks everything apart, or if giant spiders surround your camp. Then where do you get the food? You can't magically make meat, or anything. You need to get it yourself. Neither you can magically put together two mushrooms in a bowl to make excellent food, you need to cook it. and for cooking you need it's own ingredients. And you never know if your top-class cooking recipe turns out to make a big chunk of goop.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Reluctance and hesitation were the first feelings out of me when I acquired this game, mainly due to the seemingly never ending popularity in knock-off Minecraft games. However, this game quickly won me over after about an hour or two of game play.Don't Starve is a survival game as the title suggests, but contrary to the title, the cause of death usually won't be starvation, as nearly everything in the game seems to want you dead. Not much is explained to the player, aside from the fact that you and your character need to find food and shelter before nightfall on your randomly spawned island.Game play is tedious and crafty and only grows in difficulty as you progress. I find more joy in learning as I play, rather than looking up how to play or how certain elements work. I don't think you can get much enjoyment out of simply playing for an hour or so and then quitting. No, you must be persistent and be prepared to sit on your butt for a few hours in order to become properly and fully immersed into the environment. Each time you die you must start over, unless you figure out some way to re-spawn (don't worry, it's entirely possible). The map also changes every time you start a new game, so there's no worry about knowing where you are or what could possibly lie at the edge of your screen.Something I find special and charming to this game is the characters. As you progress, you can unlock unique characters, who all have their pros and cons and as well as distinctive personalities. Their different abilities can dramatically change how you view the environment given to you, whether it's for the better or worse.The main focus of this game is survival, so if you're looking to build incredible structures then I suggest you go back to Minecraft or some other such game. With that being said, after I'm able to build a comfortable base, map out the entire island, and survive the dreaded winter, I enjoy starting a new game and tormenting myself all over again.Of course, this review says nothing about the underlying plot hidden between the cracks of the updates. That's for you to figure out though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Absolutely love this game. A proper survival horror, with a gritty illustration look. You will care about not dying in this game, as if you die, your game is wiped and you start again (although there are a few in game tricks to let you respawn). You can make the game more, or less challenging with the options which allow you to change all the factors individually which is a fantastic feature and much better than a generic "easy", "medium" or "hard" mode. Sadly, this game has no multiplayer mode which would have really improved the longevity of the game, but here's hoping for a future survival game from this company which will include a multiplayer mode. I will be looking out for it! Definately give it a go if you haven't already!

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												Highly addictive; with a great Gothic/steampunk design aesthetic and a suitably spooky soundtrack, it's rather like Halloween all year round. Gameplay can be challenging at first, but discovering how to survive is half the fun. The other half is flinging mods at the game to see what will stick, what will nerf the game into boring-ness and what will make it even more challenging.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Reluctance and hesitation were the first feelings out of me when I acquired this game, mainly due to the seemingly never ending popularity in knock-off Minecraft games. However, this game quickly won me over after about an hour or two of game play.Don't Starve is a survival game as the title suggests, but contrary to the title, the cause of death usually won't be starvation, as nearly everything in the game seems to want you dead. Not much is explained to the player, aside from the fact that you and your character need to find food and shelter before nightfall on your randomly spawned island.Game play is tedious and crafty and only grows in difficulty as you progress. I find more joy in learning as I play, rather than looking up how to play or how certain elements work. I don't think you can get much enjoyment out of simply playing for an hour or so and then quitting. No, you must be persistent and be prepared to sit on your butt for a few hours in order to become properly and fully immersed into the environment. Each time you die you must start over, unless you figure out some way to re-spawn (don't worry, it's entirely possible). The map also changes every time you start a new game, so there's no worry about knowing where you are or what could possibly lie at the edge of your screen.Something I find special and charming to this game is the characters. As you progress, you can unlock unique characters, who all have their pros and cons and as well as distinctive personalities. Their different abilities can dramatically change how you view the environment given to you, whether it's for the better or worse.The main focus of this game is survival, so if you're looking to build incredible structures then I suggest you go back to Minecraft or some other such game. With that being said, after I'm able to build a comfortable base, map out the entire island, and survive the dreaded winter, I enjoy starting a new game and tormenting myself all over again.Of course, this review says nothing about the underlying plot hidden between the cracks of the updates. That's for you to figure out though.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												TL;DR version:Rating: 8/10Reason: Easy to pick up and play, hard to master, very entertaining whenever.Long Version:No matter what I seem to be doing in this game, the situations always go from bad to worse. This might seem bad at first, but it wouldnt be a survival game if it didnt do this. Whenever things go bad, you gotta find a solution somehow.Whats that? A giant sentient tree of sorts is coming to spill my guts for defiling the forest so I can gain a few measly logs? I cant fight this thing on my own? Let us befriend the local pig population to have it fight the creature for me, an army of my very own!Crafting in this game is easy to use and simple, while the materials themselves are the challenge and so fun to gather. If youre looking to pass some time on a game you dont need to think too hard on.. Well.. Maybe go for some solitaire but, if youre looking to pass some time with a game that stands out from other genres, pick up Don't Starve! I give it a very solid 8/10 (since im a tough critic)

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												The world of Don't Starve might first look like the one of Minecraft or Terraria, but many things are different, you can't just spend the night inside a house, looking out from a window. You are always in danger and you can't know when the worst will come and without any preparing, you'll easily get killed. You can't have infinite light sources, you need fuel and something to burn the fuel on every night. You always need to be on the lookout and get more food. You can't know when a giant monster totters to your camp and breaks everything apart, or if giant spiders surround your camp. Then where do you get the food? You can't magically make meat, or anything. You need to get it yourself. Neither you can magically put together two mushrooms in a bowl to make excellent food, you need to cook it. and for cooking you need it's own ingredients. And you never know if your top-class cooking recipe turns out to make a big chunk of goop.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												Redo-a-review rave!  My old review was made back in Dec 2012 and alot has changed, I've found.Back when I found Don't Starve, it was a good survival, and had round islands connected to eachother from slim 'bridges'. From the beta to now, much changed, much got added and best of all, full mod support via a lua-scripting based API was added, along with full integration for the Steam Workshop.Don't Starve is a Tim Burton-esque survival game based on living as long as you can or progressing through its adventure mode onslaught. You'll have to manage your days to thrive in this harsh environment with several well-fleshed biomes to peck your beaks at. You begin your game as Wilson. A crazed scientist hell-bent on his goal of endless knowledge, promised to him by Maxwell, a dapper fellow who traps him on the unknown island that Don't Starve takes place in.The first thing I want to say, is that Don't Starve's art style and sound design is the best I've seen from an indie game to date, with the entire game being aptly themed to its dark, humerous gameplay, a nice simple, pencil-shaded art style accompanied by lovely OST's which use exotic and well themed instruments. The character voice acting is none existant, instead, each character has a instrument as their vocals. From Willow's flute to Wolfgang's tuba, all suit the characters personality.The characters in Don't Starve are widely varied and have unique abilities and shortcomings which bring different playstyles to each playthrough, keeping the gameplay fresh and unique, while keeping you interested with what they have to say with unique witty examination lines per-character about everything. The world changes around you by itself, Beefalo (the native buffalo herds) will grow, the season will change, terrors grow in the night and the world turns more and more hostile, forcing you to go and --spoilerfied for the sake of spoilerness-- before things get too heated.Combat or survival. You can, if so inclined kill everything you can get on your spear to try and survive, or try your hand at trapping and farming, or balancing the both out as best you can. There are several random events, leading to bosses, treasures and traps as you explore the island, along with newly introduced caves for spelunking.Don't starve still has a few months of development cycles left, and a thriving community still present as it was back in '12.Oh, and its ON SALE (as of review date)!Science! Over and out.

												Would you like a game that utterly destroys your sanity? Well, this is your game! It's Brutal difficulty will bring you to your knees, and then after, thustly chopping your head off! Let me recall my experience thus far,First game:Get in, try and collect food... enjoying my time, then suddently blackness! My character, confused, comments on the sheer darkness of the night, and then, 1 SWIPE! 2 SWIPE! Game Over!Second game:survive 6 days, and then my sanity level dropped so low, that monsters of my imagination ravaged my face off with their mighty claws and teeth!Third game: Still surviving, found a good cycle to keep steady food, so i built a small fort surrounding a science machine, and others, it rains. I notice a slight increase in frogs around me, and pay no interest. I then, later try to kill one, and by now, they have surrounded my small fort, i hit it once with a spear, and it, with its giant mallet tongue, hits me 3 times, down to 10 health! Still alive though! I retreat to my fort, when then, a lightning bolt cuts through the sky, and burns my humble home to the ground, and the ashes, blew away swiftly in the wind! SUCH A DIFFICULT GAME, it will hurt you again and again, and the challenge is compellling! i enjoy this game, because it does not hold your hand, in fact, if u try to hold its hand, it will slap you across the face, and kick you while your down. 10/10 would recommend this game, verrrrry challenging, but very fun!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Don't Starve is an addictingly entertaining game, worth every penny. It is a survival sandbox game, where the ultimate goal is to... don't starve... and explore the vast wilderness and survive for as long as possible. The game is based on a rogue-like concept, which means that every time you play a game, everything is randomized. In addition, the game offers no tutorials or guides on how to play, which only enhances the aspect of exploration. This is definitely the best element this game has to offer, as there are numerous things to discover, even after 90+ hours of gameplay. As with most rogue-likes, the game can be quite difficult, and death often lurks behind every corner. The game also features permanent death, which means that once you die, you will have to start all over again, although there are ways to cheat death a couple of times. There are a number of different characters to unlock through varius means. They have emphasis on different aspects of gameplay, which can either make the game easier or harder for you. In addition, they have all a unique ability that differentiates themselves from the other characters. The visual aspect of the game is pleasing, and the audio is very enjoyable. It perfectly supplements the cartoonish atmosphere of the game.Additionally, the community is great. There is a plethora of mods and guides available. The modding community is vast and the mods can either make life easier or more difficult for you, depending on your preferences, and veteran Don't Starve players can utilize mods to keep the game alive for a long time. For new players, there are tons of guides to be found, many of which I have used myself. They are a valuable resource when you are in need of tips and tricks. All in all, a great indie survival game, which I would recommendable: 10/10

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												This game kinda reminds me of my first night in Minecraft. The game does not tell you what to do at the start, you're just thrown into the world and will have to rely on your wits and creativity to survive. However, Minecraft is a walk in the park compared to Don't Starve. Its hunger and sanity mechanic really forces you to go out to find resources to survive. In a way, it makes exploring in Don't Starve a more rewarding experience as the randomly generated world always has surprises. The art style is also pretty cool (and scary sometimes).Its a true survival sandbox in every aspect. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												This game is insanely addicting and fun, and I strongly suggest anyone who enjoys a little rogue-like survival game here and there, or even someone who enjoys Burtonesque-style things would enjoy this game. Now, for the newcomer, it may be incredibly difficult to figure out what to do at first. But the more you play, the more you'll start to get a hang of things, the more you'll figure out what to and what NOT to do. This is a quality game, and it is incredibly unique, unlike really anything I've seen before. It is well worth the money, and for those people who are on the fence, I strongly suggest you get it now, since the price will go up once they add the multiplayer feature.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game is insanely fun.  It's addicting.  I can't get enough.  In my first game I began clicking like a madman.  Collecting every little thing I possibly could.  I ignored the warnings about the night time and so I had my first death.  Round two.  I build my axe and my pick.  I start harvesting again.  I'll live this time.  I build a science machine and traps to catch rabbits.  I'm doing pretty well.  I build a spear and now I'm feeling tough.  I find some animal tracks on the ground.  I follow them.  I find and attack the animal.  I die.  Alright.  Start again.  Rebuild.  I find these friendly buffalo!  They're pretty chill.  I keep exploring.  Keep building.  Go see the buffalo again.  Why are some of them red♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  Why are they attacking me?  Dead.  Apparently when they're in heat they're aggressive.  Okay let's try again.  Build another base.  Harvest more resources.  Plant a grove of trees that I can harvest at will.  Start cutting down trees.  Tree comes to life.  Tree kills me.  I've since died to spiders, frogs, creatures spawned of my insanity, and some weird robots.  Even with as much time as I spend dying and rebuilding I never hesitate to restart and continue.  I love this game and you probably will too.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												A Hilariously fun survival game, In which, despite, the blatant instruction... you will starve ;~PThe artwork alone makes the game fantastic, along with the witty commentary and insanity that goes along with it. The game is definitely challenging, in that death is actual, no restoring to a save point, no cheat codes, if you fail to survive, you end up with your own Obituary in the Morgue.A terrific game if you are the type to poke around, and learn, however if you expect a simple mindless punch tree to get wood, use wood to make pick... and so on, there is a little bit of that, but for the most part you will be failing, starving and dying until you learn how not to do so. ;~P 1st try lasted until day six, going in and out of wormholes, setting up a base with no nearby food, near the wormhole that took me to the most desecrated lifeless land of nothingness that you could ever find... needless to say I starved ;~PP.S.: Don't Starve ;~P      x~D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Very cool little survival and crafting game.  Casual in it's gameplay but also challenging and rewarding at the same time.  The graphics are in the stylized in a creepy comic book sort of fashion that serves the theme of the game very well.  The sound design and music are excellent and only enhance the experience rather than distract from it.  Most importantly though, the game is simple to get into and features some very intuitive and streamlined controls.  Whether you're using a mouse and keyboard or a gamepad, players will be able to jump into the game and explore the Don't Starve with relative ease.  The challenge is finding the ingredients and materials necessary to survive while discovering the usefulness of each item and tool that becomes available, all while avoiding the dangerous creatures that come out at night and the lingering darkness they bring with it.    ---  The Good  ---  - Nice graphical style- Great sound design and music- Intuitive gameplay and user friendly control scheme- Made for gamers of all skill levels and backgrounds (casual and diehard gamers alike)- Both Mouse & Keyboard and even Gamepad support!  ---  The Bad  ---  - Nothing really, this game is very good all around!- The only thing that might throw off newcomers is the fact that they  will need to discover what they'll need to do within the game all on their own without very much help.  The game is relatively easy to figure out though and shouldn't cause frustration for even the most casual of gamers and newcomers to gaming.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This game seems some-what boring from the trailers, but I can assure you it's not. My friend gifted it to me for Christmas and it actually was pretty fun. I started with a lack of light my first night, and got murdered by whatever in God's name that thing was. Next, I tweaked a new world to have a lot of food. I began finding carrots everywhere. But, I found something interesting. I found what was called a mandrake. They look almost exactly like carrots in the ground, and yes, they're the things from Harry Potter. When you eat one, it cycles the time of the game to either day or night (depending which you are currently in). I proceeded to find many, many, many mandrakes. Started carrying them with me all the time. I befriended one, called him Charles. I had found almost all the mandrakes in the world. After a long time, Charles was all I had left. I'd gotten lost in a sinkhole, and my fire was almost out. I could here one of those stone monsters walking around, my heart beating incredibly fast. As my fire just went out, I whispered. "I love you Charles," and listened to the monster slowly walk towards us. Overall, I'd give Mandrake Simulator 2015 an 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												This game is a ton of fun to learn. It can be a little frustrating playing the game at first and not knowing you needed to do X Y or Z (the first time you're killed by a tree when doing something you've done a hundred times before...), but its a fun kind of frustration.This is a game that ANYONE can play but can require quite a bit of thought and experience to master. I have yet to meet someone that doens't like the game. Just about everyone becomes disillusioned with it when the mystery is gone and they learn all the "pieces", but it can't be helped. It's still worth a good 20 to 30 hours of playtime, and if you just love the game even without discovery you can always play some of the unlockable characters for a different approach.
