content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												I am a big fan of this game. It's awfully challenging the first several play throughs, especially since its primary (and I think only) difficulty setting is the equivalent of Minecraft's hardcore mode: 1 life. However, that's part of what makes this game so satisfying. Aside from feelings of accomplishment this game has a great spin on the crafting/survival game. It's artisitc style is expertly done, the variety of things to discover and create is expansive as well. The world is large with lots to explore. I have played for a... fair amount of time, and there are still many things in the game I have yet to uncover.High replay value with diverse worlds, tough challenges, several playable characters, DLC I haven't even jumped into yet, and some mods that I have seen that look like they could be seriously awesome (The Screecher). Interested in this game? Buy and play! Very much worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												Absoultely worth full price. The developers have put a lot of work into making this one of the best survival games I've ever played. The art style is fantastic, as is the gameplay. However, the game is HARD, so if that's not your thing.....buy it anyway. You can adjust the world generation to make the game easier if you like. Or even more hellish. The world is randomely generated by the way. This means every playthrough feels fresh. Which is great, because when you die, you die. All of your progress is gone. However, its always your fault if you die. Didn't have supplies for a torch, wandered into a clockwork bishop, lit a forest on fire...punched a pig. The game encourages you to learn as you play; with each subsequent playtrough you are a little better equipped to make it out alive. This is absolutely a journey worth taking. BUY IT!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Don't Starve is one of the rare games that is so atmospheric that once you start you can't tear yourself from it.  It's insane difficulty mixed with that true feeling of advancing, discovering, and conquering is a recipe for long hours of fun.  Though you can surround yourself with walls and food, the underlying creepy tone (which I absolutely love) always reminds you that death is never more than just around the corner.  This game isn't for a very casual gamer, it takes determination, skill, and will to advance anywhere, which makes it all the sweeter when you do.Overall Don't Starve (RoG included) is a hardcore, rewarding, and atmospheric game that is hard to even look away from.  I definitely recommend this game for anyone who loves the above.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2013
												Don't Starve is a survival game done in "Tim Burton" type visuals. The game starts off with you creating or generating your world on a set of options, and than you are thrown into the world without help, advice, any tools etc. You main goal is to not starve, hence the name. You must gather tools, materials, food, and start crafting your base. The game has day/night cycles, weather, seasons, etc. Tons of different cute monsters and enviroments await you in the game. You must figure a way out of the world by the evil boss at the end of the game. There are many craftable foods and weapons to make, tons to do, and caves to explore and whatnot. This game doesn't get boring. Many characters to unlock that have diffferent skills and things, like Wilson (first character) grows a beard, and other characters like the robot can eat anything. The game is well worth it, and is fun to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This should actually be a "mixed" review, but steam only allows "yes" or "no" on whether to recommend.The problem with this game is it's hardcore difficulty only. If you die you lose your saved game. The game is fun and challenging and all, which is why I do like it, but it gets boring when I had to do the first steps over and over again just to get to the fun part.Please give an option for not making it hardcore difficulty. Give us a choice.Edit:The above review was made when I played just a couple hours. Now I have played much longer, and some of my poinions have changed, so here's what I think now:The use of difficulties in a game is always something argued about. Good difficulties are challenges that makes the game more interesting, bad diffculties are nausiences. I think for this game, yes, prema-death does make sense, changing it would require changing the entire game. But that is exactly why I don't play it anymore: It was fun for the later 47-ish hour out of the 57 hours I played, but not after.So I'm changing my review to a thumb up. cheers:)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Don't Starve is a mediocre good game that you can find in the most money milking survival horror genre era.I personally dislike the Art style, it looks a bit like Tim Burton's art style ? I know it's nitpicking however I wouldn't let that get in my way since I am an avid Otaku.So I let that out of my chest, now to the game.The game requires alot of "finding things" and "crafting things" to survive, which are both core elements to horror survival game and they nailed it. Although I would really say that the "horror" part was maybe toned down a little. If you aren't patient then this game isn't for you because you would have to wait for like 2 or 3 minutes every time the game goes into nighttime before you progress on. I am not really that far into the game and I found myself dying to stupid things because I was curious to experiment with stuffs that they provide in the game. Curiosity killed the cat and the game made me do it which is not a bad thing. I love it when game does that, meaning I can get more out from what I paid.Overall it's a solid game, can't wait for the multiplayer. Although it gets a tad boring sometimes.7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Full of danger lurking around literally every turn, Don't Starve is a fantastic game. Thrown into a very unforgiving world with nothing but the clothes on your back, you must work quickly to build tools, find food, and make a shelter in the often vain attempt to survive. This game is pretty difficult, and only gets harder as the game goes on; the longer you survive, the more dangerous the world becomes and harder it is to continue.I cannot recommend this game enough to people who enjoy difficult and survival games. From plants and animals that want you dead to the very shadows and darkness of night out to get you, this game will have you huddled around just about any light source you can find in minutes. I give this game a very easy 9.5/10. In short: YOU WILL DIE.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Well, where to start?... I bought this game back when it was released as an early access title on Steam. From there it has improved and developed in so many ways that it's hard to describe...Don't Starve is a cute & sometimes a little creepy survival and crafting game. Upon starting it you're dropped in a strange and hand-painted world full of mysteries, monster and ressources. From this point you'll have to build up a base and explore the world to improve your equipment and survive against the wilderness... By discovering some in-game secrets or by plain out surviving long enough you'll unlock many different characters with certain strenghts and weaknesses... The greatest thing about this game is, that it's very content rich and open to exploration...With the two DLCs "Reign of Giants" and "Shipwrecked" even more content is added to the game. In Reign of Giants you'll have to fight far stronger enemies than before and thus develop new tactics to defend yourself from those new creatures that were added to the game. You'll also have to face new environmental threads, such as dangerous and unforgiving deserts.The newly released DLC "Shipwrecked" features the exploration of a tropical version of Don't Starve, featuring completely new bosses and items, giving the game a nice and new kind of concept and tactical approach.I certainly recommend this game to anyone whos interested in open-world survival games. Don't Starve can be very harsh and unforgiving on the player, but uppon learning from your mistakes you'll survive longer and become better and better until you finally "beat" the game. I can also recommend both of the DLCs since they are extremely well made! Have fun playing and good luck surviving!

												Best game I have ever played. For the money I have had hours upon hours of fun. If you don't have this game I recommend you to buy it now. I will never ever be sick of this unique game and amazing art style. Plus the DLCs for this game are both cheap well made and like a whole new game. Last but not least the modding community is one of the best and will always be there to renew any lost interest. 11/10 game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												A disturbing, slender, and well dressed gentleman bids you to wake up, and insists you find food before nightfall. What he doesn't tell you, is that come nightfall, should you be lost in the shadows, something terrible might happen. Several days pass since the start of your adventure, and you may feel pretty good about yourself, your supplies, and your structures. Just know that nothing is permanent... nothing.In Don't Starve, you're thrown into a sandbox survival game mode immediately. There is no tutorial. Death is your tutorial. Learn from it. Your goal, to find out what your goal is. There is no hand holding. Figure it out. Because if you don't, you will enevtually die. If you find out, and are ill prepared, you will also die. Take your time, but don't waste it. There is also a door, somewhere in the world. Within it, you may find answers.I was very skeptical of this game at first. "Oh great" I said, "Another sandbox survival game. Just what we needed."Then I played it, and I was hooked. The gameplay manages to be fun, rather than tedious like so many other survival games. The art style is distinct, and reminiscent of Tim Burton's older works. Each playable character works a little differently, adding to the game's replay value.This game is like being in an abusive relationship with a sociopathic puppy. In that you never know what it wants you to do, it actively tries to make you miserable, but you can't help but love it. All in all I am very pleased with this title. I would reccommend it to anyone who enjoys survival games, structure defense games, or someone just looking for a good challenge.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Don't Starve is my all-time favorite game, and might I say, that's quite an achievement since I play a lot of games on a daily basis and am part of many game-related fandoms.DS has a silly air to it at the beginning, but the longer you play, the more you realize how deep it actually is in terms of variety. The gameplay may be confusing at times but it's generally user-friendly and has nothing a few bug fixing mods won't fix. The storyline may seem shallow but it's altogether quite interesting if you're really into DS as a fandom more than just a quick play and actually want to know the characters' personalities and such.It's a nice, well put together game that can work as either a quick 1h play and a 24h marathon without getting sick of it. I made sure to buy as many copies as I could to my friends because it was just that fantastical, and I've been in love with this game ever since its first steam release.If you're into survival games as much as I am and want to explore the world rather than to just stick with one base and fight off crazy monsters that won't let you enjoy the entire experience, then it's one game for you to consider.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												As a fan of these type of games (in which you have to work and work to get what you want - ex. Harvest Moon, games like that) , I recommend this game to those with a lot of patience and time, who won't just quit in frustration after the first few plays. If the gameplay doesn't drag you in, then the plot-line will if you follow it. The Tim Burton style gives it a nice, creepy touch that I applaud it for. The mechanics are well-implemented, and the time-management factor is a great touch to it, since you may have to plan out what you're going to do and how long you have to get to a certain area, what's more important to focus on for a day (dedicating a day to rabbit-hunting, chopping wood, tending to a base) and so on and so forth; some survival games don't put this in very well, but this one certainly does. Sometimes it does get a little frustrating, but once you get the hang of it, it gets very fun and addicting; you never know what's ahead until you explore. 10/10, definitely would recommend.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Don't starve is one of those Indy Games that you like, play fore a while, get addicted to, play a little longer and the put it away for a year or so to start the process again later on.The way this game plays, feels and is being experienced just works for me. the art feels both safe (mainly because it is cartoony) and yet dark too. And for a game in which the dark will kill you and you'll have to create light to stay alive that is great! At night you'll be terrified while feeding your campfire with the last pieces of wood, and during the day you'll be ready for an adventure to gather supplies, food and weaponrry for the next night (and day).I must admit, after playing it for too long it will get boring. mainly because it's still an indy game which just isn't build for great scale and an unlimited supply of options (Except for the all-known Mojang Project, if you get my drift). But, after a while, you can pick it up again an loose yourself again for a couple of weeks (maybe months).For the price I would say it is definately worth it! Great and addictive to certain extend, 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												One of my great fall back games. Even before the Reign of Giants DLC the game received much love in the form of updates by the developers. In the game you start out as Wilson, you are pulled in to a bizarre world and someone named Maxwell and you basically have to survive. There are two implicit game modes (you don't have to choose they just both are there) to play. One is just the pure survival in a bizarre world and the other is to find the person who got you in the world and "deal with him "Both things are really entertaining to do. The game is hard enough as it is on its default standing but you can change any custom generated world as you please. If you don't like a world all are random generated so best start a new one. The game has its own art style you either love or hate. Its got a unique atmosphere and an isometric 3rd person view when playing the game (camera can be turned)I personally just love this game and every once in a while check what has been changed. I'd say if you like how the game looks, like a challenge, like random generated worlds, like survival games and this art style, than this game is for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												This game probably doesn't need another positive review, but I've been having fun with, so I'll add one.  It is essentially a survival crafting game where you try to outsmart the world (which is constantly trying to kill you) in order to live as long as possible and discover it's secrets.  The best aspect of this game is discovering secrets, so play without instruction and discover all these secrets for yourself.  It seems simplistic in the first few hours; then you realize there are lots of fun surprises that let you overcome seemingly impossible obstacles.You will probably die a lot in this process.  And when you die, you start over.  It can get frustrating.  But if you put it down for a while, you will want to come back to it.  The game would have benefited from 'undefined' achievements; e.g. achievements where you don't have instructions on how to achieve them.  This would provide a record of what you have discovered without giving you a grindy laundry list of things to do and wouldn't make you play for the wrong reasons.  The developers (and particularly the forum mod) have a strange attitude of not allowing discussion of development decisions on this topic and others, which is off-putting for those who like to discuss the games they play, but it does not directly impact the enjoyability the game itself.It's a lot of fun, has a great art style, and definitely worth playing.  I only hope it doesn't get too repetitive before I'm able to survive adventure mode.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												You awaken in a strange land with no memory of how you got there. A mysterious figure notes that "you don't look so good", and tells you to find something to eat, before vanishing. So begins your adventure. You are Wilson, gentleman scientist, and you have been cast into a world that looks like it was conceived and drawn by Tim Burton. Your goal: survive and thrive. To succeed, you must maintain Wilson's physical health, sanity, and, yes, hunger level. The world around you is full of resources, which can be destroyed, collected, and combined to create tools, shelter, food, and so on. As you progress through the game, you become more adept at magic and science, giving you the ability to shape the world around you in fantastical ways. Beware, though. The world has a copious supply of monsters, traps, and obstacles, and death is always only a misstep away.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												I am a big fan of this game. It's awfully challenging the first several play throughs, especially since its primary (and I think only) difficulty setting is the equivalent of Minecraft's hardcore mode: 1 life. However, that's part of what makes this game so satisfying. Aside from feelings of accomplishment this game has a great spin on the crafting/survival game. It's artisitc style is expertly done, the variety of things to discover and create is expansive as well. The world is large with lots to explore. I have played for a... fair amount of time, and there are still many things in the game I have yet to uncover.High replay value with diverse worlds, tough challenges, several playable characters, DLC I haven't even jumped into yet, and some mods that I have seen that look like they could be seriously awesome (The Screecher). Interested in this game? Buy and play! Very much worth it.

content:

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												At first, I really didn't understand Don't Starve. I was dying all the time and it was really hard. It didn't seem like there was much depth. I quit for a long time and stumbled upon the reviews for it one day and thought to myself, "Why does everyone like this game so much?!" I had to try again. What I discovered is that what I perceived to be a lack of depth was an excess of suckiness on my part.I looked up walkthroughs and was like "Okay, I got dis."The truth is, you really don't got dis. Unless you obsessively invest time into this game, because you refuse to die yet another time after such a, what you believe to be, wise investment of time and genius in the relentless wilderness of Don't Starve (which seems to happen to everyone else).In truth, this game is a whole lot of fun, albeit frustrating. There is no lack of persistent challenge, upset, and especially the thing that keeps you going, an overwhelming sense of accomplishment and discovery. The possibilities are endless. And what keeps you coming back is the heartbreaking failure when a giant deerclops somehow destroys everything you have spent hours building in mere seconds. By that I mean you keep playing out of pure spite and vengeance. It's all in good fun!

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												To start with I will give a little background, I got this game on the PS4 when it was free for PS+ members, so I have played much more than the Steam number shows. This is quite possibly my favourite indie game I have played.Don't Starve is an incredibly good game, it has great depth and incredible replayability. There are many different characters you can unlock, each with unique traits that will make replaying this game continiously enjoyable. I would highly recommend buying this game, even if it is not on sale, although it does go on sale frequently.The DLC Reign of Giants expands upon the world of Don't Starve by making the game even more challenging, by adding 2 more seasons, Spring and Autumn and reworking Summer to be much more difficult. It adds many new items that can change the way you survive. And with the new mechanic of smoldering items in Summer, the game gets a lot more difficult. I would also highly recommend purchasing this DLC because it adds an incredible amount of content to the game.The new DLC Shipwrecked is also very good, with a completely new theme and many new game mechanics it is another great way to test the skill of the player. The new boats and rafts that you can build and the new mobs and adaptions of the seasons make this DLC incredibly fun. It is in early access, so there are going to be a few bugs and not all features are implemented yet, but it is incredibly fun so I would recommend purchasing it.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												This game isn't fun, it isn't relaxed, and it isn't easy to understand. This game requires you to learn from your failures (or the failures of others), it demands constant resource and time management, and sometimes it can be down right cruel, But this game is a rush. You will be scared of anything that can kill you (which pretty much includes everything in the game). You will be paranoid, expecting your demise around every turn. But it is precisely this fear of a world thats out to get that makes exploiting it feel truely rewarding. If you can work up the nerve to rely on your skill, risking the loss of your progress and forcing to learn and start from scratch, then mastering this game will prove to be a challenging and rewarding experience.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This should actually be a "mixed" review, but steam only allows "yes" or "no" on whether to recommend.The problem with this game is it's hardcore difficulty only. If you die you lose your saved game. The game is fun and challenging and all, which is why I do like it, but it gets boring when I had to do the first steps over and over again just to get to the fun part.Please give an option for not making it hardcore difficulty. Give us a choice.Edit:The above review was made when I played just a couple hours. Now I have played much longer, and some of my poinions have changed, so here's what I think now:The use of difficulties in a game is always something argued about. Good difficulties are challenges that makes the game more interesting, bad diffculties are nausiences. I think for this game, yes, prema-death does make sense, changing it would require changing the entire game. But that is exactly why I don't play it anymore: It was fun for the later 47-ish hour out of the 57 hours I played, but not after.So I'm changing my review to a thumb up. cheers:)

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												Absoultely worth full price. The developers have put a lot of work into making this one of the best survival games I've ever played. The art style is fantastic, as is the gameplay. However, the game is HARD, so if that's not your thing.....buy it anyway. You can adjust the world generation to make the game easier if you like. Or even more hellish. The world is randomely generated by the way. This means every playthrough feels fresh. Which is great, because when you die, you die. All of your progress is gone. However, its always your fault if you die. Didn't have supplies for a torch, wandered into a clockwork bishop, lit a forest on fire...punched a pig. The game encourages you to learn as you play; with each subsequent playtrough you are a little better equipped to make it out alive. This is absolutely a journey worth taking. BUY IT!

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Don't Starve is a GREAT game. I don't have much play time as of me making this review, and that's becuase I mostly play Don't Starve Together.  Don't Starve is a game where you play as Wilson (when you start), a wanna-be engineer/scientist. He makes a portal to this mysterious world, once he hears Maxwell's voice on his "radio". Once he builds the machine, Maxwell urges him to pull the switch. But Wilson Had made a mistake. You wake up on a completely random generated island with Giants (if you have Reign Of Giants Add-On), Spiders, shadows, and way too many things to explain right now. Maxwell says "Hey buddy. You don't look so good. You should find some food before night comes." And that's it. You can do whatever you want. Why did Maxwell want yo to build that portal? You have to craft the divining rod, and fight out yourself. But I do urge you to grab this game, and the Reign Of Giants DLC. You can also unlock charecters (sorry for spelling) further on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 27, 2013
												Don't Starve has a lot going for it in the way of interesting rogue-like mechanics, but it still feels like a work in progress despite its 'release' status.  A few failed attempts to figure out what's what and most players will likely be able to sustain themselves indefintely -- or, at least, to a point where they are bored enough to quit or find the objects necessary to teleport to another map.  Many items seem pointless/overkill as the vast majority of enemies can be killed with easily craftable log armor and spears.  There are unlockable characters but the variations are minor and gameplay is the same.  All of that said 'Adventure' mode provides a  NG+ challenge after you've mastered the basics.  A solid game but it has the feel of a pet project that could do with a lot more development time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												The very first thing you may notice about this game is the unique style, sketchier and darker than other games of similar genre I have seen, yet still pronounced and very easy to recognize. As you play the actual game, though, you begin to see the complexity through the little details from your hunger and health to the spoilage of food, range of temperature, and changing of seasons and weather among many other things. Simply put, if you go in just expecting a little fun and easy survival challenge, you may find the whole world of Don't Starve opening up and encapsulating your interests with its subtle hints of folklore and storytelling.In my personal opinion, loving story and complexity to said tale, I think Don't Starve is an amazing game that has captured my interests moreso than any other recent game titles I have played. Of course, this game is not for everyone. This is one of those games that drops you in with the only hint that too is the title of the game, don't starve. If you have no clue or introduction, it can be difficult to figure out how to survive, as there are no clues as you play, but you can decide with what you are given to do most anything. This includes modifying your world to the difficulty or ease you please, but if you want to participate in the story more thoroughly, I recommend trying out the Adventure Mode, but this you cannot modify as it is randomly generated. I won't give any spoilers to the elusive story or specifics of the game, but something to the charm of this game is the characters themselves. Each has their own unique design, strengths, weaknessess, abilities, and personalities. Most of these unlock with experience you gain from either dying or escaping your world ( details excluded), but some are Reign of Giants exclusive and require certain actions to be taken to unlock. I still must say that without these characters and their diversity, it would take away so much from the experience. The community, too, has made some phenominal mods for the game, including characters, and I say go and give 'em some love as they make this game even more enjoyable.Something else that plays an important role is the music, or lack thereof. At times you feel helpless and alone, wandering this strange land uncertain of what to do or where to go, and other times you may be picking flowers to the happy tunes of day and relax as pronounced notes finally signal the end of a dreadful night. While sometimes non-existant, I find that whenever the music plays I become even more caught up in the soul and feel of the game.Overall, I recommend this game for its uniqueness of style and play, development of environment, character, and story, and for the community Don't Starve has created that I am proud to be a part of.Thank you very much for reading my review!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												What struck me as a quality that is rare and should be in most modern videogames is Don't Starve's ability to make you learn from your mistakes and try again. To not make this annoying, they've softened the blow of the mistake with a little something special.You must have heard a critic claiming that Don't Starve makes you start an entire world again just because you died. First of all, you're provided many opportunities in the game to have a respawn. But dying isn't so bad. Assuming you've survived enough days, you receive a new character! It's neat how Klei Entertainment took the time to develope the well written characters Don't Starve has to offer (except for that one mute character that's meant to be more of a challenge than a character) After unlocking each new character, you can clearly make out each of their interesting personalities and views. Along with being well written, new characters have interesting ups and downs (like unique weapons in Team Fortress 2) that can suit or even  benefit  your playstyle! But there isn't one overpowered character, each is unique and fits everyone differently, real neat. My favorite character is Maxwell, not because of his abilities but because of the heartbreaking backstory he has, play the game to find out what his astonishing plot is! To keep this short and sweet, my rookie review covers only a very small part of what I enjoy about Don't Starve. That's right, I don't normally write reviews but Don't Starve made me dive straight into this positive review writing when I've decided that more people need this treasure in their lives. Alright, here's some more review I can dish at you. After playing this, it didn't make sense that the price is as low as it is, I figured it should be $20. It's only $15 dollars! I can't comprehend that! You go ahead, whip out some dough and buy yourself a Don't Starve right here and right now. Save a couple dollars for the soon to be released "Reign of the Giants" DLC that's been recently announced. Surely, they've been cooking that one up for months. The DLC can't be more than $5.Happy starving!tldr: Well written characters, well written plot, good for sandbox game lovers due to its increased creativity and decreased objectives, real cheap, HELLA GAME.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2013
												A good mix of surrealism and survivalism, Don't Starve is a game that immerses you into Wilson's struggle against the world he is trapped in. This game will make you value the importance of being prepared against every known (and sometimes, unknown) threat, and the value of company, as well. Amongst the many harmful elements of this game, we find: Monsters, Time and Weather, your worst three enemies, as you will be constantly at the mercy of getting attacked from (apparently) harmless bees trying to defend their hive, to giant beasts, threatening your life with every step they take; you will have to struggle against time, to make use of every precious second before the dreaded night falls down and, trust me, scary things happen in the dark; and even your fight stretches up to weather, where you will feel the constant threat of every winter coming down to chill your bones if you are unprepared. But one of the most important things to keep an eye on is food, since, after all, your objective is to Don't Starve, so you must think carefully before eating that lucky carrot you found on the ground, or maybe that steak you cooked after fighting a fierce beefalo, because you never know when will you have the fortune of finding another piece of delicious and coveted food. With an assortment of unlockable characters (with unique perks, each one), random generated and customizable worlds (so your experiences will always vary), survival (endless mode that ends when you die, once and for all) and adventure (challenging set of five consecutive world, each with different conditions) modes, a fitting soundtrack on every situation and a beautifully aesthetic created universe, Don't Starve is definitely a game you will keep coming back to.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Looks simple but it takes practice. A trial and error game. Don't get too frustrated, as the learning curve is there, but you can climb it quickly. Don't get too invested into your character at the beginning, learn the tier 1, then progress. Could use more variety in the music but I enjoy what is there.You could play the entire game with a mouse, or (I prefer) use a keyboard and only use the mouse for menus and toolbars.A variety of characters to choose to survive the wilderness, each with a personality their own.The download content Reign of Giants adds some new things. I can't comment much though, as I've not played much.Overall, a fun single player game. Worth full price.I've not put many hours into Don't Starve, but I've played Together (The multiplayer beta that supports up to 6 players, that comes free with launch) 40+ hours. I find that to be more fun, even though it's in beta (not all the content, and no RoG content).Really, though my hours are low, that will change as time goes on.Also has a good modding community, can't forget that.Well, I'm done. Good luck to those who brave the wilderness, you're going into the wild.Edit: Some Reign of Giants content is in the Don't Starve Together.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Don't Starve is one of the rare games that is so atmospheric that once you start you can't tear yourself from it.  It's insane difficulty mixed with that true feeling of advancing, discovering, and conquering is a recipe for long hours of fun.  Though you can surround yourself with walls and food, the underlying creepy tone (which I absolutely love) always reminds you that death is never more than just around the corner.  This game isn't for a very casual gamer, it takes determination, skill, and will to advance anywhere, which makes it all the sweeter when you do.Overall Don't Starve (RoG included) is a hardcore, rewarding, and atmospheric game that is hard to even look away from.  I definitely recommend this game for anyone who loves the above.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												As awful as I am at this game, I can't say anything bad about it. The art style is awesome, as is the soundtrack. There is so much to do in this game, and yet, depending on how difficult you made your world (which you can customise to your skill level), you'll see just a small part of it before actually learning how to play well enough to get further. However, I wouldn't consider that a downside - the difficulty just makes you play even longer. I guess it's similar to Minecraft in the way of surviving (especially through the night, where, if you're not in the light, you'll be attacked by the darkness.) Saying that, I wasn't prepared for the creepiness of the game, with the bizarre creatures that might be peaceful but, more oftenly, will try to tear you apart. The combat can be a bit frusturating at times, and you really need to get out of the way when an enemy attacks, because you'll get hit no matter what side of it you are on. That being said, there's also multiple characters to be unlocked, all with different stats and abilities (and if you get tired of those, the workshop has plenty more!)TLDR; It's a great game with wonderful graphics, and I would recommend it to anyone who likes sandbox-survival type games.
